DON'T BUY THIS! I prefer AirPods 2 generation a thousand two hundred times these fall too much from your ear and you don't notice BIG difference in the sound purchased with AirPods 2 generation that loss of money I will return this and I want to order some new AirPods 2 generation

I just received my Airpods 3 and I'm sharing this view as an initial thought.,I'm writing this after returning 2 Airpods Pros to Best Buy. The sound on the Pro was too flat for my liking. After tweaking with the audio settings on my phone to no improvement, I returned the first pair thinking it was a hardware issue. Best Buy gave me a second pair which, after trying, wasn't different from the first. I sent it back expecting to exchange for Airpods 3, but that branch of Best Buy in my city did not have Airpods 3 available so I resorted to Amazon where there was a generous discount due to Black Friday.,Now, all  I can say is that if you're looking for quality sound choose the Airpods 3 over the Pro. This is because, although the Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) on the Pro gives you some quiet in noisy places, it compromises with the fidelity of the sound. After using it for sometime, the Pro sounds like some cheap earphones. The Airpods 3 has much more pronounced bass without sacrificing the high sounds.  Besides all this, it has all the features of the Pro, including Spatial Audio, save ANC and Transparency. On the 3, you'll enjoy natural transparency  and you wouldn't miss the ANC as other airpods give you better ANC.,Other advantages that you will enjoy in the 3 over the Pro is its lighter weight plus 6 hours of uninterrupted listening which is such a boon if you're the type that keeps your Airpods in your ears for longer hours. The charging case also offers you about 30 hours of juice which means you can charge your Airpods up to five times before needing to charge the case. Did I add that the 3 is water resistant including its case and that it has skin detection feature which will not play your music in case you leave the Airpods in your pocket? To me, the 3 is a slight upgrade of the Pro and the previous generations of Airpods.

The 12.9 inch iPad Pros have a mechanical design problem that will eventually lead to inability to charge the iPad.  This is my second 12.9 inch iPad Pro.  The previous one had the same problem.  The USB-C charging port is not sufficiently secure.  It has lateral play that eventually causes an internal connection to break rendering the iPad useless requiring an expensive repair.  The internal connection may be a solder joint or a thin buss on a flexible printed circuit board.  I don’t know the actual design, but some connection will eventually break.  My first iPad was a 3rd generation iPad.  I assumed the lateral play in the USB-C was normal since it was the first iPad Pro to use that type of connector.  After a couple of years, it failed and Apple wanted $700 just to open it to see what was wrong.  Instead of paying for the repair, I purchased an 11-inch iPad Pro.  The cost was about the same.  The 11-inch does not have the lateral play issue.  The USB-C connector is very solid with absolutely no movement.  I really missed having a 12.9-inch for my digital art so I ordered this 2021 model, hoping that Apple fixed the problem.  As soon as it arrived, I checked the connection.  Sure enough, it has the same connector play as my original 12,9-inch.  I immediately repackaged it and will return tomorrow for a full refund.  Sadly, I recommend you stay away from 12.9-inch iPads until Apple corrects this flaw.

I haven't owned any Apple product in like 10 years so was hoping to enjoy that quick & easy onboarding experience that people rave about.,Instead my iPad asked for ancient passwords and expired credit card numbers to log into my Apple ID. Obviously I didn't have that info, so I requested a password reset. It took their robot 24 hrs to "review" my request.... and then I got an email saying it'll take 2 weeks to reset?! 2 WEEKS?!,Until then I'm staring at a +$1k brick...

Unfortunately, Apple does not allow multiple user accounts on an iPad. I knew this used to be the case a decade ago, but when I finally plunked the dough down for this glorious new iPad I was appalled to find out you can only have a single Apple account linked to the device.,Back it goes, such a shame, the whole family was so excited but not having this 101-level feature makes it not worth the price.
Sent me a iPad that someone returned.. was also missing the charger and charger cable.

I bought this iPad to replace my Microsoft Surface Pro, which I was never completely satisfied with. I had never owned an Apple device before, so there was a slight learning curve to get used to the non-Windows commands and functions. The screen is extremely sensitive, so I had to learn to lighten my touch quite a bit. Email was a snap to set up. It took me about 24 hours to download all the apps that I needed. I was able to transfer my photos and certain other files from my android phone. One weird thing I learned, you can't text non Apple devices. That seems unnecessarily exclusive. You need to pair the iPad with an iPhone in order to text Android devices, so if your phone is an Android you are SOL. There is an app available that let's you text android devices, but it assigns a whole different telephone number, so that is very confusing to the person receiving the text. Another weird thing is that the iPad does not have a headphone jack. You have to use Bluetooth ear buds. I have not tried to set up Bluetooth earphones, so I can't comment on how easy, or difficult that may be. For me, this is definitely not ideal. Wireless ear buds need to be constantly charged up, and I find them uncomfortable and they easily get bumped out of my ear. That being said, the display on the 12.9 is beautiful, and the larger size works really well for on line zoom meetings and video lessons. The battery lasts all day, so far. Time will tell if the battery life deteriorates as the months go by.
I love it!!! Feels like a computer but in a better way you know !!! 10/10 it’s a must buy!!

This is honestly my favorite way to use a computer. HDR 4K content is great, and it gets pretty loud so my wife and I can watch something together. I watch a lot of lecture/educational content often while taking notes. The large extremely high definition screen makes reading text in a video easy, or easy to share the screen with my note taking app.,It’s not perfect though let me go over some things that could improve.,The bezels are so small holding it can be awkward.,The mini keyboard makes typing while holding easier, but I wish the mini keyboard had a bit more like a number row.,The blooming can be annoying, but it’s basically only noticeable during load screens.,The camera probably should be positioned for landscape video calls not portrait.,I wish I could play nes and snes games on it. It has more than enough power to run emulators, but without jail breaking there is no side loading.,This thing is expensive, but if you think you want to use a tablet. This is the one.,Side note about me: I use a one plus 6 Android phone and my computer is Linux/windows so I’m not an apple fan boy. I do think the iPad is by far the best tablet computer. I did have a MacBook Pro and it broke and I learned why repairability is important. Don’t buy something you can’t afford to replace it. So get AppleCare+.

This is my 4th iPad, I have had the 2nd gen, the 4th gen, and the first generation 12.9 iPad Pro, and this 12.9 M1 iPad Pro by far the best one yet. The XDR Liquid Retina screen must be seen to be believed, but needs to have UHD HDR content for it to really shine. The new chips made it sooo fast, I hope future software updates will take advantage of that speed. I purchased the 256Gb storage with 8Gb memory, because the 1Tb model with 16Gb memory was out of my budget. I see on YouTube some of the pundits say that the 12.9 iPad Pro is too big and heavy, I ask is a sheet of typing paper too large, and at 1.5 pounds only a very small child would deem it too heavy to hold. I bought the Apple Pencil and Apple Magic Keyboard, later purchased the ESR Magnetic Smart Case/Folio and relegated the Magic Keyboard to a desktop docking station. Don’t get me wrong the Magic Keyboard is good but it is so heavy and adds so much thickness I just don’t want to lug it around, better just on the desk. The Smart Cover is very light and thin and also has a flap to keep the pencil in place, easy to carry around.

The product itself is good. The downside is for artists like myself. While using procreate, it overheats often and will basically turn itself/make itself unusable until it’s cooler. The thing is, it doesn’t feel hot at all. Not sure if this is a product error or if it’s for real. Pretty disappointing when you’re grooving along with your art and then you have to take a forced break.

Battery life is worse than an comparable Apple laptop. Brightness is a bonus as it does get brighter than a laptop but for whatever reason Apple chose miniLED which has excessive and unacceptable light blooming (especially if you use dark mode). They use OLED on the iPhone and reach 800 nits and OLED TVs are plenty capable as well, should have gone OLED and I’m sure they will which makes this a subpar “transition” product. Also, only one USB-C port in a space where this is competing with laptops with twice to four times the number of USB-C ports.

Really amazing headphones. Sound great, noise cancellation is 10/10, comfort is 9/10 (you don’t even really notice the weight). So as for headphones go, these are awesome.,The 3 things that keep me from giving it 5 stars:,1) Condensation. It’s real and it’s worrisome. Condensation constantly forms when using these. You remove the ear pad (it detaches easily cos it’s magnetic) and you see lots of water droplets. Not sure if all over the ear headphones do this and these are noticeable only because you can remove the cup, but until Apple releases a statement about it I cannot recommend it to anyone. It very well may be accounted for and is not going to affect the headphones’ longevity, but again, Apple needs to release a statement already.,2) The price. $549 is a lot,3) the case. just wtf. why they did that,If Apple comments on the condensation, i’d bump it up to 4 stars.,Had an issue when they were delivered but it was more on Amazon rather than Apple. Amazon really took care of me though, so 5 star for that amazing Amazon customer service.

First off, I'm not saying DONT buy the AirPods Max, in whatever color you desire. BY all means, please get them, they are a fantastic paid of headphones, comfortable in everyway, amazing sound quality, worth every penny, especially if you enjoy music and are deep into the Apple ecosystem like a lot of people are.,What I am saying is DO NOT BUY these from Amazon. I bought 2 pairs back to back, returning BOTH of them. Why?,Because they were NOT new. They were both used.,Neither of the packages came with the Apple arrow pull shrink wrap. They both had stickers on the outside of the box, stickers that werent put there by Apple. One of them even stated "Would you like to add Adeel's AirPods Max to your phone" ?,I may have been one to experience a fluke, maybe even 2 in a row, but I wasnt about to give them $500 for used headphones. I'll be buying them straight from Apple for full price and happy to do so.

Straight up -- audio equipment is subjective.,Do these sound fantastic? I think so.,Are the comfrotable? For me they are.,How does the ANC perform? Its second-to-none.,Are they worth the $550 asking price? Probably not.,Honestly, if I wasn't already heavily (but also happily) invested in the Apple ecosystem (I write as I type this up on an over-priced MacBook) I probably would've skipped on these bad boys -- but I am and the benefits the H1 chips and the sweet macOS/iOS-only features only sweeten the deal.,If you're not as wrapped up in the Apple ecosystem, as I so pathetically am, you would probably be better served by a pair of Bose QCs or Sony XM4s. That being said, I have thoroughly enjoyed just sitting in my chair with these cans strapped on as I zone out to my music while society continues to crumble around me... that, to me, is worth the $550 investment.

After I perused the specs and got over the sticker shock of the price tag, I thought, “These might be worth the investment for me.” I have high-end hearing loss, and because of that, most speakers, earbuds, and headphones don’t do much for me. I have an especially hard time hearing dialogue on our TV unless the sound is being pumped through our HomePods. That is what caused me to pause and really consider the purchase. “What if the AirPods Max is like putting HomePods on your ears?” That was worth it to me.,After setup was completed, I put the headphones on my ears and heard the first sounds through the AirPods Max. It was a Christmas song that I had heard dozens of times before. The sound was so rich, deep, and clear that it was like I was hearing the song for the first time. “Ok, there is no way these sound this good.” At that moment, Robyn, my fiance, walked into the room and said, “So, are they like having HomePods attached to your ears?” All I could do was nod yes. She gave me a look and I handed them over to her. She put the headphones on her ears and scrolled through my library until she found something she wanted to play. She then said she had to have a pair.,When I test headphones, I have a few go-to songs I like to try out so that I can get an idea of the listening experience of the headphones from every angle. The songs are pulled from a variety of genres including soundtracks, rock, grunge, punk, classical, and even a bit of rap. The AirPods Max does an incredibly nice job with all of them. The headphones keep a nice, deep bass sound while protecting the integrity of the rest of the track. I also found that vocals are crisp as well and I really love that as I turn up the volume, that I don’t get any distortion. That’s not been the case with other headphones I’ve used.,Overall, I’ve been impressed with all the features of the AirPods Max. Here’s a brief rundown of my thoughts on the main features of the headphones.,Active Noise Canceling (ANC): Until I used the AirPods Max, the ANC on the Sony headphones was the best I’ve ever used. I took the Sony headphones on a flight a few years back and never heard the airplane’s engine noise. Therefore, I’ve always regarded the ANC on the Sony MDR-1000X as the ‘best’. While I haven’t taken the AirPods Max on a plane yet, I can say that it deadens ambient noises like dogs barking, vacuums, and TVs that are left on in the background.,Mesh Headband:  I love the look of the headband. I think it looks very clean and it accentuates the lines of the AirPods Max. The design is right up my alley.,Weight: I’ve heard some people say that the weight of the headphones is an issue for them. I have noticed that they feel a bit heavier than other headphones I’ve used, but the weight seems evenly distributed to me and so it doesn’t bother me. I’ve worn the headphones for several hours at a time and have not had any issues with headaches or soreness.,Buttons: I am a big fan of the buttons. This is odd for me to say since I never thought I would be a proponent of moving to analog from digital, but Apple did a nice job of blending in the Digital Crown and the ANC button.,Smart Case: This is one thing I would have reconsidered if I were designing the AirPods Max — the Smart Case. I really consider it more of a ‘sleeve’ than a case because — well, that’s what it is. The sleeve is made with a single piece of what seems to be polyurethane material and utilizes magnets for the closure. While the sleeve does protect the metal earpieces of the headphones from getting scratched up, for the most part, it doesn’t protect the headband and there is even a cut out on the bottom that leaves the headphones exposed to the elements and potential damage. I also noticed that when I take the headphones out of the sleeve that the AirPods clink together. The only way I’ve been able to stop that from happening is if I physically place my hand there.,Even though there might be a few minor things I would like to see improved about the AirPods Max, I’m absolutely thrilled with them. They are far superior to any other listening experience I’ve had and think that their price tag is worth the investment. Even though the cost is prohibitive for many, if you want the ultimate listening experience, I can’t recommend the AirPods Max enough.

For the past ten years I have enjoyed and been dependent upon noise canceling headphones. With that has come a journey into the audiophile community with others who are on a quest for high-fidelity sound. My journey led me to many headphones that sound absolutely pristine but none with  noise canceling and few are wireless. Until late, the Bose Noise Canceling 700 are my compromise for great sound and noise canceling in a wireless headphone. So, when Apple announced the AirPods Max, I had to try them to know how they compare to my Bose 700. Here are my conclusions so far...,STYLE,The fit and finish on the AirPods Max is absolutely beautiful!  Love it much more than the Bose. I just like the way they look and feel. Before I purchased the AirPods I probably watched 50 unboxing and review videos. So, I thought I had a good idea of how they looked.  They are nicer in person.  Sleek, premium, modern and minimalistic.,COMFORT,Comfort is about the same!  AirPods Max are definitely heavier but do not necessarily feel much heavier on he head as the weight is balanced well.  I have larger ears and the ear cups on the Bose 700 go a little deeper to make room for my ears. So, over several hours, the Bose do feel slightly more comfortable. The Bose also do not get as warm as the Apple.,TRANSPARENCY MODE,Transparency mode, in my opinion, is actually more natural on the Bose. The Apple headphones actually amplify the sound around you a few decibles too much. In other words, things sound louder than they actually are with the transparency mode on the AirPods Max.  Also, the Bose reproduces your own voice much more naturally when in transparency mode.,SOUND QUALITY,Sound quality at certain volume levels is almost exactly the same. Kind of unbelievable. It is as though Apple reverse engineered the Bose 700 and copied its sound signature and noice canceling to within 5 percent. There is  a definite sound quality difference though that changes with the volume level. This is all about the DSP. Of course, the digital signal processing (DSP) is called Computational Audio on the Max and Volume Optimized EQ on the Bose. This is what works differently and what accounts for sound differences dependent on the volume. Basically, the Bose sound better at 60 percent volume and below. Bose just has it dialed in so that everything sounds rich and balanced. I usually listen to music at about 55 percent volume on my iPad. So, I prefer the sound of the Bose. The sound at 60 percent and below on the AirPods Max suffers from a veiled upper midrange. An alto saxophone, for example, will sound as though it is being played behind a wooden door.,Now between 60 and 70 percent volume is where both headphones sound virtually the same. It is uncanny! Both sound absolutely wonderful. Probably the best you will ever hear on wireless noise canceling headphones (yes, the Sony has an amplified and unnatural mid-bass making them sound deep but not high fidelity).,At 70 percent volume and above the Bose DSP begins to lower the bass response to avoid distortion. The bass gets progressively quieter as you increase on the Bose to where there is virtually no bass at about 90 percent volume.  The AirPods Max, on the other hand, handle bass very nicely from 70 all the way up to 100 percent. In fact, they sound perfectly balanced all the way from 60 to 100 percent volume with no sound quality degradation. If there is a fault it is that the bass looses a little nuance. In other words at high volumes the bass is a little over controlled.  The softer vibrations like on the trail of a bass string get lost a little.,So to summaries the sound comparisons.  The two headphones sound equal from 60 to 70 percent volume. The Bose sound bette at 60 percent volume and below. Finally, the AirPods sound better (by quite a bit, it’s not even close) at 70 percent volume and above.,CONTROLS,The final comparison are the controls. Apple wins in my book.  The Digital Crown has a perfect feel to it. It rotates very smoothly with a perfect amount of resistance. It presses well also. Apple has hyper dialed-in these controls. It makes me never want to have to use the touch-pad on the Bose 700 ever again.,WHICH ONE IS FOR ME?,Everything is comparable on these two headphones, but in the end, sound quality at my preferred listening level wins out. Since I listen to at about 50 percent volume, the Bose continue to be he choice for me. I just have a fixed routine for when I use noise canceling headphones.,Now, I am sure that Apple could probably update their firmware to adjust the computational audio in order to fix the balance issues below 60 percent volume. If they did, then the fit and finish and controls might win me back over to the AirPods Max.  But, the slight compromise in long-term comfort would cause me to hesitate a little.,ONE LAST THING,One last thing, the spatial audio is pretty Amazing. If I had to watch movies on my iPad these headphones would be a must. The surround sound effects are as good (slightly better) than my Bose home theatre system. The overall sound quality for movies is slightly less (more sterile and hollow sounding, probably because of the limited Bluetooth codec) than my Bose home theatre system.

I decided to spoil myself and try these out. Reviewers say they're excellent and have the best ANC/transparency mode out there, and they damn well better for $550. So are they all they're hyped up to be? Is Apple taking the audio world by storm and revolutionizing music as we know it? No. Not by a long shot.,I'll try to categorize and simplify my thoughts:,-Build Quality:,  In classic Apple fashion, the hardware is very good. Metal and high quality fabrics are present, no Apple logos or graphics to stain the clean and sleek design, and the magnetic replaceable earcups are genius (albeit expensive at $69 a pair).,-Controls,  The button/knob wheel combo is simple yet effective. I much prefer physical buttons to touch controls (The Sony WH-1000XM3's have infuriating touch controls and apparently the M4's aren't much better) and Apple does it right. One button to switch between ANC/transparency mode and no mode at all, and the knob to control the volume as well as play and pause. Super simple, as it should be. However, I couldn't help but notice how little resistance the buttons have, which makes them easy to press. This resulted in me accidentally pressing something almost every time I put on/took off/adjusted my headphones if I grabbed them from the top. Just something to note.,-ANC/Transparency Mode:,  Transparency mode on these is EXCELLENT. Voices almost sound like they're in your head and everything is made not only louder, but clearer as well. Much better than the Airpod Pros. The ANC however, to me was a bit of a let down. It was difficult finding the different between ANC and no mode at all, but I suspect this might have something to do with....,-The Fit,  I have a big problem with the fit. It's a little hard to explain in text but I'll give it a shot. Ideally, when the headphones are put on, the main cans sit flat on your ears and are parallel to each other to create a nice seal around your ear, like this  {|  |}  . But due to the hinge design that connects the main cans to the headband, they have too much area to move around in a sense, and they end up fitting more like this  {/  \}  , which results in too much pressure being applied at the top of the main cup and not enough at the button, creating an opening at the button of my ear where not only the music escapes through, but outside noise bleeds in as well. I have tried every length and adjusted them in every way possible but that is an unavoidable flaw in the design. Could it be due to my weird head shape? Possibly, but it's not something I've never experienced in over-ear headphones, so I'm blaming Apple for this one.,-Sound,  So they don't fit well and ANC is balls. Could the sound save it perhaps? Will you weep in joy at the Apple engineering that made such beautiful vocals and trembling bass possible? No. I would call it average. SLIGHTLY better than the Airpod Pros. My V-Moda M-100's, almost a decade old, sh!t on these, spit in their face, curb stomp them, pick them up, then sh!t on them once more, all at half the price (and they straight KILL them once I connect them to my FiiO BTR5) all at half the price or so. Sound is okay, bass is lacking for me, volume is shockingly low. Just an overall disappointment.,Final Verdict:,  These aren't bad headphones at all, not by any means. Great build quality, banging transparency mode, and average sound. But for five hundred and FIFTY DOLLARS it should be FANTASTIC sound, with SILENT ANC, and more accessories than a single cable and a DIAPER for a case (which is frankly pathetic). There is much better out there for cheaper. I personally recommend the Sony WH-1000XM4's (I actually have the M3's but they're apparently really similar to the M4's so not enough for me to upgrade but great deal for first time buyers). Great sound, great ANC, great fit, comfortable, wonky controls but not a dealbreaker, with actual useful accessories and a proper carrying case at half the price. Or V-Modas. Or Sennheisers. Or Airpod Pros. Anything within the $200-$300 range really will do anything these do and most likely better. I generally like Apple products and can justify owning my Airpods (both regular and Pros), iPad, and even the Watch, as they offer an experience I just can't quite get with other products, through the hardware and software, but these are a giant swing and a miss, and I will be returning them within the week. I am not rating it 2 stars because they're bad. I am rating it as such for the incredibly bad value for money you're getting.

I like the sound and the fit (after changing the silicone tips size to find the most comfortable one). Some reviews complain about this not being a new Airpod model, which is true. The product description is clear that the upgrade is only for the case.,If you want to know which case you have, look inside the case on the left airpod's side and you will find the serial number and model. The model for the magsafe case is A2190, introduced in 2021. This is different from the airpods model that you can see from the phone Settings > Bluetooth > YourAirpodName (click the (i) for info), and you will see the model number. As of the date of writing this review, there are 2 possible model numbers introduced in 2019 (A2084, A2083). You can also look at the airpods themselves and you will find the model number written in a very tiny font on them. One side is A2084 and the other is A2083.

Looking thru all the reviews and most of the negative ones are about battery life not satisfactory. I have tested my Apple Watch series 7 with not having the “always on” display and found that if I turn that setting off I only burn 25-30% battery in a full work day 10 hrs. I don’t know about you but if I’m not looking at my watch, why would I need the display on? When you turn “always on” display feature off watch display comes on only when you look at it immediately and that’s perfect for me. Just go to display and brightness on your phone in the Apple Watch app and turn off “always on” . Think about if your phone had a setting where it was always on……it would be dead in no time and everyone would be complaining the battery doesn’t last.

Apple does a lot of stuff well.  Mac Books, iMac, iPad, and iPhone.  As a fitness tracker it is excellent and how it integrates so well with the iPhone, but as a watch is another matter altogether.  The short battery life, the rectangular watch face limiting details, and no seconds indication when in low-power-always-on-display mode are all big drawbacks.,The Apple Watch will get you at around 26 hours on a full charge. This is completely unacceptable if you are frequent traveler or someone who falls asleep with their watch on.  It is one more thing to charge in such a short time.  Your phone you put down after some time, but a watch is used more frequently.,Sometimes in 2022 or by 2024, Apple should introduce an Apple Watch which has greater than 36 hours in a round face.  Until then, save your money.

I really want to love these. I own every version of the AirPods from Gen 1 to the Max. The AirPods 3 are almost there but in some ways a step back from Gen 2.,Sound: The drivers are much faster than Gen 2 and have a lot of clarity with every genre of music. The bass is a lot, lot more pronounced due to the size of the resonance chamber and proximity to the air canal. (To get a good bass sound, you need a good seal.),The Spatial Audio is honestly not a big deal at all. I think if you want to be wowed, look into playing your music through a dedicated DAC/Amp.  The Dynamic EQ lives up to its promises playing music with a higher degree of clarity and neutrality only found in the AirPods Max. The Pros come close after the most recent software updates. However, when connected to a non Apple device, the Pros have a very bass heavy sound.,Regarding sound leakage, these leak more than the Gen 1 and 2 design. I would say that at 50% volume or higher, people around you will hear what you’re listening to.,Fit: Apple managed to create AirPods that fit worse than previous generations. For my ear shape, the AirPods Pro actually hurts the cartilage due to its thicker body. So yes, they are more comfortable than the Pros. They are also noticeably lighter than the Pros despite being fairly similar in shape and size. If you own the Pros, take off the detachable ear piece and put them in you ears for a rough, approximate size.,Case: If you’re in the market for accessories to make them stay in your ears better, I’m not sure it’s possible due to how little extra room there is for things like ear hooks. The case itself feels and weighs very similar to the original AirPods case. Everything about the previous versions feels the same in terms of materials and mechanics.,Charging: Charging is as advertised. It can be wirelessly charged with a MagSafe pad or a Qi wireless charger. The downside of using a Qi charger is that the heat that seeps into the case and wearing down battery life. The downside of the MagSafe pad is that the strength of the magnets requires two hands to pull it off. This can also be seen as a plus if you have a cover for your case.,The charging port is a Lightning port and not USB-C.,Hardware: Despite having the same H1 chip as the Gen 2 and Pros, the AirPods 3 are snappier than the Pros (even when I’ve compared them to a brand new pair of the Pros) when it comes to connecting and switch devices. The new skin sensor does a good job of quickly detecting when they’re in your ears which I’m assuming leads to faster activation/ deactivation. The only other AirPods that switch just as quickly are the AirPods Max.,Also, the AirPods 3 don’t suffer from an issue with the AirPods Pro where the audio plays on speaker when you take your AirPods Pro’s out of your ear quickly.,Overall: I really wish that Apple had done more testing to ensure fit. This is a pretty strong performance being as close to “audiophile grade” without all the extra work of IEMs, wires and other hardware. However, since they easily fall out with any activity, you have a limited range of motion when using these — driving, walking, etc. The AirPods 3 are a mixed bag!
The sound quality is what you would expect from Apple. Overall, I’m happy. They do sound better than the original AirPods.

As another person said these are made for people who don’t like silicone eartips and enjoy the previous generations of airpods everything is good about them the only cons are,This is likely Not meant for people who have small ears, as i’ve read some pointing this issue so beware of that, they are bigger compared to previous gens.,No ANC ( Active Noise Cancellation ),Pros (imo),Buttons that are easier to tap and play/pause audio that doesn’t cause you to move the airpods themselves.,Spatial Audio is the best feature to use, as it upgrades the quality of how much more audio you hear, as well as where you move your head from your phone or any compatible device audio is adjusted in each pod to follow your movement.,If you’re an Airpods Pro fan & love ANC but want spatial audio i’d say wait & save your money til the next release sometime in the future (You won’t be missing out for much longer). Otherwise i recommend getting Airpods Pro for just about $20 more, or Gen 2 if you don’t want ANC, have more average sized ears, and don’t need Spatial Audio. Hope this helps anybody! Nov. 4, 2021
The only real problem I had with this item is that the pods are made for people with large ear canals which I do not and they kept falling out.  Returned them for the PROs and I am happier.

I have owned every kind of AirPods made, thus my excitement for the new AirPods 3. In short, get these for the much-improved sound quality, presence, and that noticeable bass, which most earphones lack completely. They are worth the cost over the AirPods 1&2 hands-down. Given the $180 list of the AirPods 3 and the observation that AirPods Pro are sometimes around $200, I think the sound is good in both (Pros not that much better) but with the noise cancellation in the Pros, they win on flights, commute, and offices.,Now the rub; the Airpods 3 just plain HURT my ears over the AirPods 1&2. I know the shapes are similar but somehow the AirPods 3 are slightly larger and press against the upper rim of the ear. After an hour, I need to remove these and reach for the old AirPods. The '3's' hurt as bad my ears as the Pros. And now, I've noticed that the left ear ALWAYS falls out! Ugh, sending back my '3's' - who cares if the bass is good if they hurt to wear.,Too bad. I love the new sound but the pain is so annoying. Make sure you keep the box, since you may need to return these, sadly.

Had these for a couple days now and first thing to notice is that the SIZING IS TERRIBLE. As many have mentioned already, if your ear holes are ginormous, these will be no problem for yall. Mine are on the smaller-to-average size so throughout the day, I notice them loosening/falling out from regular-use, daily activities.,As for the sound, they're pretty nice. Upgraded from 2nd Gen so the tones are definitely noticeable in improvement. I'm sure the sounds would be even more enjoyable if these fit my ears.,MANUFACTURING IS TERRIBLE. I'm very good at taking care of my belongings and I've come to notice a rattling sound in my case... As if there is a loose part running around. If something like this is louder than shaking an hourglass, that's a no-no. As for another complaint, the left earpiece fitment is noticeably off as well. The rounding half that fits onto the other half of the earpiece as a bit of a sharpness to it (due to improper fitment/alignment) and I can occasionally feel that friction in my ear--WHEN IT DOESN'T EVEN FIT ALL THAT WELL!,Anyway, I'm returning these. Have a nice day yall.

I loved the Gen 1 and 2 AirPods and had to return the AirPods Pro’s after a cpl days because I could not get those ear tips to fit comfortably no matter what size tips I used.,The overall earbud is slightly larger than gen 2 so if you have small ears like my fiancée then maybe it’s best to stick with Gen 2s for the comfort. However, if you have normal to large sized ears than I highly recommend the 3s.,You get used to the larger earbud size after a cpl hours of wearing them then they are super comfortable like the Gen 2s. The stem is also noticeably shorter and looks better aesthetically.,The main improvement for me was the sound quality and addition of spatial audio. Thought this was all gonna be a gimmick but dang these do legitimately sound better than the 2s even without spatial audio and not all songs have spatial audio functionality but most new songs do. Don’t forget to toggle spatial audio on/off from the control screen so you can hear the difference.,Noise cancellation is slightly better than the Gen 2s because of the physical size of the ear bud but they are by no means noise cancelling; if you need that then the Pros would be a better bet.,All in all I’m super happy with them after a few days and love they just pop into your ears and fit snug like the Gen 2s. Highly recommended!

If you like the 2nd generation AirPods, you’d like these.,Sound Quality: If you’re upgrading from the 2nd gen AirPods like me, then you’ll love these, the sound on the 2nd gen AirPods were always quiet for me, I’d have it almost turned all the way up and could barely hear, plus the quality wasn’t very good. Now these AirPod’s (3rd gen) wow! The sound quality itself is so nice. You can have it on 1/4 volume and hear perfectly.,Fit: I used to have the 2nd gen AirPods and they were a pretty good fit, but they were a tad bit loose, like it felt like it was falling. Now these AirPods (3rd gen) they’re slightly bigger, they fit nice but don’t really go into my ears personally, it kinda just sits there but it’s stays in so that’s good.,Battery Life: the battery life on these are amazing! I can be listening to music for like 15 mins and the charge only goes down by 1-2 percent, they last a long awhile and the charging case as-well, way more than the 2nd gen.,Overall I’d rate these 3rd generation AirPods a 8/10, I highly recommend you get them especially if you have the 2nd generation. These are a nice upgrade.

If you have smaller ears and perhaps liked the Second Generation AirPods, these are not for you.  They are much larger than the Second Generation and did not stay in my ears.  I wanted to love them due to the sound quality (EXCEPTIONAL) but I would not feel safe going for a run or even any kind of jumping exercise with these in.  On top of it, when they did stay in, say just sitting still listening to something or on a call, they really hurt that little ear flap after a while!  People say the Pros are better (even though they are the same large shape) because of the adjustable ear piece, but I don't see how that would help the comfortability factor.

I’ve had these for just over 1 month.  I have been resistant to replacing the basic, Apple wired earbuds, but finally caved because it seems inevitable that we are all getting pushed into a world where wired earbud support will completely disappear.  (For now, we are saved by adapters)  I really tried to be open minded and patient with these for the past month.  Sound quality is ok, (though I swear my Apple wired buds actually sound crisper/cleaner),  case/design is gorgeous. They happen to fit my ears perfectly.  Wireless to replace perfectly working technology (wired earbuds) at many many times over the price, and with many many times problems including trouble getting them to connect to my device and audio being continually interrupted... horrible experience!!!!  I wear earbuds primarily to help me focus on my work.  Throw that out the window when audio cuts out between 10 and 100 times per hour... urrrrrgghh frustrating.  I only caved and bought these because everyone seems to insist how great they are.  I hate them and regret the purchase.  Unless you just buy products for bragging rights, run away from this, and don’t look back.  I could have bought a lifetime supply of wired earbuds for these pointless excuses to put highly volatile/explosive lithium ion battery powered devices snugly wedged in our ears, as close as possible to our brains, airpods.,—- UPDATE —-,I changed my review from 1 star to 4 stars. Once I got a newer iPhone, the audio issues seem to disappear.  Pardon my overly negative review above..  that said, I am leaving my previous feedback given that the AirPods *should* have worked with my older iPhone.  I still don’t love the idea of earbuds that must be charged, and I’m still convinced the sound quality is not as good as my wired pair.  As long as these are working, though, I’m content enough.  I don’t think I could ever give 5 stars for a $180 pair of earbuds, but I guess that’s more a me problem than an Apple problem.

Processes on the iPad are very slow due to the CSAM scanning they implemented. Apple sells user data to advertisers and is one of the least privacy focused companies out there. That plays into the iPad and everything you do is tracked and sent to Apple. They even enabled iCloud backups unencrypted by default at the request of the FBI, so make sure you turn that off immediately. Wouldn’t buy another. Apple sucks.

Very disappointed.  Was eager to get my ipad pro but then i saw a dead pixel on the screen.  contacted amazon support and asked me to "massage" the screen.  offered me 10% compensation which is 70$ for the trouble of returning.  also, amazon cannot exchange for a new one.  dont know why.  apparently because of the high price value.  in the end, i returned it.  note that if there is a dead pixel, there is a high probability that there will be more dead pixels in the future.
My new I pad pro worked for 2 days then froze. I have not been able to use it or reset. Was on the phone with apple and they tried also.  Expercom says it cannot be returned. Terrible company!!!

I purchased an iPad Air first, and I had an issue with it, so I returned it. In the back of my mind I really kept thinking about the new M1 chip, so instead of getting another iPad Air, I upgraded to the iPad Pro.,Performance wise, there is no difference that I can tell. The iPad Air was super responsive and fast in all tasks.,I do like the face recognition better, when it works correctly. I don’t have to do anything to open my iPad, and that is better compared to the Touch ID. The new Touch ID works great though, much better than the old version. The issue with face recognition is that sometimes it wears you out asking you to use your password to open your iPad. I don’t like that at all. I was told that the iPad will learn my face better in time, and I will not have to use the password as much. I’ve turned everything I can password related off, and added as many different face scans as possible.,The FaceTime camera being 12mp is awesome. It’s nice to press the flip button and take selfies in 12mp. They look amazing.,Even though I probably would have been fine with the iPad Air, I do feel better knowing the M1chip will probably add a few years of use at the end of this iPads life cycle.

No info on getting set up, just trial and error procedure.  Can't go online as the ipad only goes where it wants to go.  It takes hours of trying and most times I just give up as you can enter the location you want to visit but this takes you where it wants you to go.  It is so obvious it is just trying to control my spending and push its agenda.  I am crazy enough without the aggravation of this inexcusable excuse for wi-fi use.  It takes far too long to get things accomplished, that is if you ever can.  Horrible..HORRIBLE.  I have limited internet service and this just eats up my usage without any accomplishment.

This device is amazing. Sleek, fast with m1, screen is beautiful.,All that Apple needs to do is to update iPadOS so that it has better:,1) multitasking and windowing support;,2) a file management app that actually has a format media and an unmount media function (as it stands you can’t currently unmount your external disk safely on iPadOS14.. which can lead to data loss, and you also can’t format a disk using the iPad);,3) multi-monitor support that uses the full aspect ratio of the external display and can display in extended mode. As it stands, the current implementation on iPadOS is to display a mirrored image of the iPad’s screen onto an external monitor. There’s no ability on a system level to display a separate image on the external monitor (some apps have this function but it’s a per-app feature rather than a system wide feature). This defeats the whole point of using a monitor with the iPad in the first place. I don’t want the image to be mirrored.,The second issue with multi monitor support is a more egregious limitation in my opinion.  That is, the iPad will not by default display an image on the external monitor in its native aspect ratio. Most monitors these days are 16x9 or 16x10, but the iPad will by default display its image in 4x3 mode, meaning there will be black bars to the sides of the image on the external monitor. This is egregious. The iPad only uses a portion of the external monitor instead of using the whole screen. The very same m1 chip inside the iPad Pro is also inside of various macs, and all of these m1 devices except the iPad can display an image to an external monitor in the monitor’s native aspect ratio.  So this is a limitation that Apple has chosen to allow to exist.  Apple really needs to fix this.,But other than these quirks and limitations, the iPad Pro is a fabulous device. I love it.

I have had this iPad since the 1st of September.  I cannot download games, I cannot get the Cisco Webex Meeting app to learn how to troubleshoot, and THERE ARE NO DIRECTIONS FOR USING THE iPAD.  Very poor support.  Local Apple store does not have help in the store.  I will need to travel over 10 miles to get spurious help.  Very poor product.

Can’t find 1 external sd card or usb drive that works even if the vendor says it will, you have to use multiple dongles for everything plus have a hub that you have to keep powered by a cord line and then it might work, etc…oh, and try to find an app that you can use to read the attachment…haven’t found one yet…and try to plug a hub in if you have a case on…..I can do more with my Apple IPad Air 2 which is ancient! NOT worth the 1000 dollar price in my book! Cords, dongles for everything that are plugged into a power source all the time….can’t even plug into a computer without it sending you to some online network database to even copy to the device…maybe I will find something that works with this thing that is of use to me…I will keep looking…
The color is perfect and it works great.  The best part was the setup was a breeze by putting my other IPad right next to it and everything transferred over to the new one.

I bought this Ipad brand new and it was defective right out of the box. It kept turning off even when the battery was 100% charged. At first I thought it was just a minor issue but when I contacted Amazon and a technician ran all the tests it kept doing it. I was told someone else was going to contact me for follow up the next day and gave all my info and no one ever called! Is really shocking how Amazon could take that so lightly when is such an expensive item, brand new! This Ipad was the latest model and costed more than $1,000. Finally I called Apple and scheduled an on person appointment on the Apple Genius Bar for the next day and they were amazing and replaced the item with no questions asked for another brand new IPad closed in the box. It was opened in front of me and tested before I went out of the store. The technician also passed all my data to the new one. So thanks Apple! I recommend you buy this products directly from them and not from Amazon.

It is a great tablet but the size is way too big for portability and casual use. (12.9 inch) Definitely for individuals with bigger hands. Also, the software is lackluster. If you’re getting this to replace a laptop be prepared to be disappointed. It’s still a TABLET. That’s it. Finally the huge black bezels need to go. It’s dumb that the new m1 iPad did not get a redesign. This years iPad is a money grab as the iPad cannot utilize the full power of the m1.

I’m really happy with Apple, their quality, software, design, …. This iPad is also incredible powerful and for sure more than enough for most applications. The perfect solution for every Apple fan with an iPhone, like me.,BUT: as I have the whole day my iPhone in my hands and “manage” everything with that during the day, a tablet is for me primary a device to watch some movies in the bed (without light).,I said to me “let’s buy the new iPad with Mini-LEDs and the great contrast. With real black and not a dark grey as every iPad I had before”…,I saw many reviews on YouTube and they mentioned a blooming, but finally always say that the picture is great….,For everyone who does believe that: watch the first 2 minutes of Star Wars VII. I stopped after that and sent the tablet back. You will never get that out of your mind and cannot watch any movie again in the dark.,It’s really sad but I found the perfect picture in a dark environment with an Android tablet. I will come back to iPads when they have OLEDs.,If you never watch in a complete dark room: buy the iPad!

It’s better than previous versions BUT unless you are using it for heavy duty applications you won’t see much difference., It is faster.,The picture is better. (See photo, version 2 versus this one),But not a very noticeable lot of either.,If you are using your previous version for lightweight applications such as spreadsheets, surfing, etc., save your money.,Were it not for a broken screen on mine think I would save my money and return this one, still might.

First off, What bloom?  I don't have any distortion at all on my 12.9 inch mini led screen.  It' is crisp and clear when watching intensive HDR content or regular content.  Blacks are black, colors pop, beautiful screen.,I would recommend it to anybody.  I didn't go for the 1T with 16GB ram because I just don't need it.,Go for it, you will love it.

Well built, excellent performance.,My only problem is while is clearly performs better than my old 2nd gen 12.9, it isn't massively noticeable right now. Webpages load in faster. A few games run quicker but for other day to day tasks? Meh.,I do like the screen, but it isn't jaw dropping. It is just....better.,My previous model had all the bells and whistles (512GB, Cellular), but using an iphone a hot spot was just as good and after reviewing my storage usage, I sat at a whopping 46GB after 4 years of usage so this model offered more than enough storage along with the updated screen and M1 processor.,I sold my 2nd gen unit when I purchased this one, but in hindsight if I still had my 2nd gen there is a strong chance I would have returned this one as the cost to perceived performance upgrade for my needs just wasn't compelling enough but in the end it is what it is and I do like it.,Still, like always, I find myself using it extensively on a daily basis and it just works and gets the job done so kudos to Apple.,5/5

This is a tablet meant for professionals and students imo. If you're busy consuming media, just save your money and the get iPad air. I'm using this for video editing, photo editing, graphic design, and using it when going for my second college degree to take notes and help with everything else in between.,And as for the screen bloom, it's not there lol. You people complaining are on drugs or need to clean your glasses. The pictures everyone posts complaining about it, your camera will make it look terrible and “bloomy” 🙄. The display is perfect for editing photos. Once again, if you’re consuming media mainly, go buy a cheap android 😂

I’m loving the iPad Pro so far….. I purchased it mainly to get a bigger screen than my regular iPad has. I don’t plan to use it for graphic design or anything so I DO wish that they offered a regular iPad with a larger screen vs having to shell out the $$$ for a Pro model.,My only complaint is that the iPad screen does have quite a bit of bloom around a white text on a black background. This is VERY noticeable on videos where you have a light colored text on a black background, but I haven’t noticed it very much on videos that are moving. If you’re using the iPad for anything graphic design related you may not like the bloom on the screen in instances where you’re doing light design on a dark background and frankly at this price point you’d expect a better screen.,If you’re looking for your first tablet, iPad is the way to go (especially if you have Apple products at home already). You may want to consider a cheaper model if you mainly plan to use for web browsing, light video watching.

This is the best value of the Apple watches - all the functionality at a great price. The battery life could be better, but it charges quickly and lasts a full day even with a lot of workouts! It's also thinner so doesn't get caught on the cuff of a coat or sweater. Tracking is excellent and although I don't wear it to sleep (if you wear it to bed, you have no time to charge unless you take it off during the day). I love the available APPs and the number of cool watch faces! It's a super-star!

I wanted to be pleased with this device but am somewhat disappointed in the fact that all this fitness information is only for a week. If you want to be able to track monthly or yearly totals, you have to download “HealthView” app and pay $30 a year for that, although they give you the first year for $14.99.

The Apple Watch se is my first smart watch. After using it for some time I can say I love this watch so much! It’s usefulness as an extension of my phone is worth it! I have only good things to say about this watch. The only thing that could improve it is if it came with a power brick for the charger. I don’t have the latest iPhone so I don’t have a usb type c charger brick. Luckily for me my laptop does so I can use that to charge my watch. All together I say this is a very useful smart watch. It’s cheaper than other models and much better than previous series (or so I’m told). 10/10 great smart watch!

After doing much research and comparing all of the apple watches, I finally decided to purchase the Apple SE.  So far I really like it.  It has everything I could ever need, plus more.  The only thing that I hate so far is that the battery life doesn't even last 2 days.  Previously I had a fitbit, which looked like my apple watch, and it's battery lasted an entire week.  Even with the battery issue, I would still recommend this watch!
The charger that came with my watch has a weird end. It won’t fit into any of my other Apple chargers.

Great watch. Has a lot of features that I’m still learning. The fitness and sleep data are mediocre. The watch is very comfortable. Battery life is not the best. I have to charge daily, you can probably turn off some features to save on battery life.

In a nutshell…worth the price. It does more than I could want it to do. There are so many features I have yet to even explore. I was hesitant on getting this bc did I need it? No. Did I really need/want to spend the money when I had a fit bit? No. But so glad I did. The only complaint I have after having it for a few months is the battery life last much less than my fit bit did. My Fitbit would last me like 4 days where this gets me maybe 2. But it could be that I’m doing much more on my Apple Watch like voice to text, music, and just playing around with it trying to learn it. Get the watch, thank yourself later.

I am 73 years old. The week after I purchased this watch I fell. This watch immediately alerted to ask if I needed emergency help. The emergency button was on screen available for me to press if I was injured or could not get up. It requested confirmation that I did not need help. I wish I had it earlier this year when I had broken my foot from a fall, rather than hobbling to a phone I could have just pressed the emergency button. Thank you, Apple Watch.

None too pleased about a couple things: Made in China, and didn’t come with a USB-C charging block. Now my pretty new watch sits here dead.

I can’t figure out how to turn specific things on or off, and it even vibrates at four in the morning to tell me if it needs to be recharged, or if there’s any other insignificant thing going on. Luckily my wife already had a charger. The next was that this thing really only has a days worth of battery life. I have to take it off so often and forget to put it back on. Initially, I never wanted a Smart Watch. Then, my husband got one & I thought his was pretty cool. SO I started looking at one similar to what he had (a Fossil), but was unable to find something I liked, or could even tolerate. Since I have (and love) my iPhone, I decided to look into the Apple watched, and found this one on Amazon. Although the price was rather off-putting, my husband & I decided that, with all of the health benefits the watch has, I should go ahead & order it. Well, since getting the watch. I've worn it all day, every day, and I simply think the watch is AMAZING! I can check my heart rate throughout the day (something I need to do), and keep an eye on my blood sugar levels (since I am a Type One Diabetic, and have the DexCom App on my iPhone, it also shows on my watch--how cool!). The watch encourages me to stand up a couple of times an hour, which is great, since I work from home & sit at a computer for eight hours/day. I love that I can make/receive phone calls from the watch, too. In the week that I've had my watch, I've found that I use my watch more than I use my iPhone. And to think that I was so.very.opposed to getting a Smart Watch... Now, I don't know how I ever got by without it.

I have every generation of AirPods and so far these are my favorite for everyday use. Sound way better than gen 1-2 and the pros and much more comfortable.,The pros suck for working out and long use times cause of the tips. Pressure in the ear builds up for many and they get uncomfortable after long use. The pros are incredible for flying and being in loud environments though that's for sure.,These gen 3 will absolutely be my go to AirPods now and my pros are going in my travel bag.,My gen 1 and 2 will be cleaned and given to family members who don't have AirPods. Since I have no need for them any longer with these out!,Lastly, those with smaller ears may still prefer the gen 1 & 2 design for comfort/fitment though since the gen 3's are larger fit and have spacial surround mode which sounds pretty incredible with a good source.

I purchased these AirPods multiple times each arriving with different issue. I’m ver disappointed. I believe Amazon is selling a lower quality variant. The first one I was sent was scratched and we’re extremely quiet. The second pair had poor plastic quality. The seems of the plastic weren’t flush and there was a noticeable ridge. Lastly, I received a third one and it had an annoying buzzing sound. And the magnets were messed up one the right bud. The magnet would catch in a different place every time i put it in the slot. I decided to return all of them because they were not up to apple standards. When returning I lost $20 because I applied credit and Amazon said that their credit is non refundable. This is the first and last time I will ever be buy Apple products from Amazon!

It's so disappointing to pay extra for the "newer" version of something only to find out the old version was better. This is exactly what happened with the gen 3 airpods. If you love your current airpods just hang on to them. It's getting really annoying that apple only tells you about the "new" features and doesn't tell you what you lose when you upgrade.,First they changed the shape so it doesn't fit your ear as well as the prior version. I have to try to jam these in my ear and they constantly fall out. Be sure to try them on before you buy them.,Secondly, they got rid of the super useful tap controls and replaced them with the less useful 'force' control. Which means instead of just tapping your airpod to pause or accept a call you have to feel around your whole head to find the tiny little magic spot on the tiny little stem of the airpod (which is in your ear now since it's shorter than before) and gently pleasure it until it does what apple wants it to (NOT what you want it to- see below). Why anyone would think squeezing the thing would be better than just a simple tap is beyond me. you have to use at least 2 fingers to gently message the stem in just the right way, rather than just a one finger tap (while you are also holding your keys or wallet for example).,Last but not least if you are planning to customize the way you use them (the gestures), like you used to be able to do on the OLDER cheaper version you can forget it. That's gone. Can't customize the new ones. You just have to learn the 42 preset apple gestures of squeeze once for this, three times for that, now spin around and squeeze the other one for siri. It's maddening.,I wore these for an hour then spent 3 hours trying to figure out how to adjust the gestures before i gave up. I immediately went back to my old airpods (gen2) which are far superior to the new more expensive ones. i will probably re-gift these to someone for xmas and I will definitely be betting another gen 2 set.

These earbuds work really well. They’re comfortable in my ear even when laying on them. They stay put. One has fallen out two times total, and one of those times I knocked it out by accidentally hitting the stem while reaching up.  The sound is really good. These come with the sound feature that makes the sound seem directional. In other words, for the first couple days, I kept pulling them out to make sure they were working because the sound from the earbuds seemed like it was coming from my phone. It makes the viewing experience seem more natural. These are not the noise cancelling kind. I can still hear what’s going on around me, which is how I want it. I can hear if someone needs to talk to me without anyone having to yell. I can hear my environment well enough to be safe, but not so it ruins my listening experience. The sound is crisp and clear. They’re rated to last 4 hours before needing to be recharged, but I’ve gone a little longer. They seem to peter  out one at a time, so you can actually charge the dead one and continue using the other one and then switch when the second one goes. This has been helpful for marathon phone conversations. I don’t think this works for listening to content because pulling out one earbud causes the content to pause - another cool feature since you don’t have to find the pause button when you need to stop for a minute. It automatically stops for you and picks right back up when you put the earbud back in. Do you can accomplish the pause by pulling out just one bud. You can always squeeze the post to pause as well. They charge up quickly in the case. The case charges quickly as well (and lasts at least 30 hours between charges).  I bought a silicone case for mine and they still charge easily on the charging mat. They can also charge using a regular lightning cord. I’ve done both with no problem. They do work with you Find My app, but I think it’s just the case that it finds. This is a problem if you’re bad about taking them out of your ears and just leaving them around the house. No handy ping for that. I’ve dropped mine a few times. They seem pretty sturdy - no cracks or other damage.  I love that my jack is now free so I can charge and listen at the same time. I really like these.

I always love my 2nd gen pods, buy this one for trying out the new features.,FACTS:,1. Good apple sound quality: good enough for everyday use and anyone who is not very picky.,2. People says it has better battery life, but I didnt use it all the time so didnt really matter.,3. The touch control is like the wired headphone you have to squeeze it, one for pause, two for next, three for last one.  Good and bad, some people dont like the tapping in the second gen, i actually like the tapping bc when you need to pause it, its faster to do (like you meet someone and need to pause the music), and to squeeze you need two fingers.,4. It hurts my ear even after a couple mins of wearing because the pod size is bigger, especially if you are wearing a hat that covers the ear now in the cold days, the hat will press it even more into your ear, so this depends on the people ear structure but i would say if your 2nd gen fits fine it might be an issue. Plus because of the tighter fit, I feel the surrounding sound is more distorted but not quiet like noise cancelling.,5. Still no volume control on the pod which is disappointing, its not hard to make volume control like touching it up and downs in 2021.,6. The so called spatial audio thing, it only supports certain things which i have not been able to find except the testing lol, probabaly not needed for everyday uses.,7. When the pods are not playing music and it is very quiet around, you can hear some background electric sound which is not in 2nd gen, barely noticable unless its very quiet and not playing.,8. The in-box charging cable is TypeC to Lightning.,Overall a good pod, but I prefer the 2nd gen not only because it's 50 bucks cheaper but overall better imo. Happy New Year yall!

1. Amazon sells the new iphones with a subscription scheme that was flagged and declined by my credit card.,2. When I first turned on the new phone, the battery level sat at 68% ---something I've never experienced before with any of my previously owned smart phones.,3. I charged the phone to full battery on the morning of 1/4. Made about two hours of phone calls (reasons given below) and downloaded like half a dozen apps. I went to sleep on the night of 1/5, past midnight; the phone showed it had 35% of power left.,I woke up this morning, checked up the phone at around 10 and it has shut off!,Totally defective phone.,Disclosure:, Before I was even fully aware of the battery issue, I had wanted to return the phone since I had to wait for 6months after the device was activated to be able to use it during a trip abroad (I blame Apple and the deals they made with the carriers). But Amazon refused to return the funds to my credit card, telling me they could only refund gift balance even though I used my credit card to purchase the gift balance as the phone purchase was flagged as fishy and I needed it to arrive before my trip.,Regardless, this battery should deter anyone who is planning on purchasing a NEW phone that is truly worthy the 729 full tag price; AND THEY CHARGED THE PRICE OF AN UNLOCKED PHONE.,I would never buy a high-ticketed item from Amazon again.

I'm a sports guy, I don't need a phone with a humongous screen nor expensive, proprietary wireless headphones, which battery lives diminish within time and are unrepairable. So, you can assume I was not happy when Apple --and later, its copycats-- had the "courage" to remove the headphone jack from their products. That's why I have been happy with a first-gen iPhone SE that I haven't "upgraded" since 2016. I decided to give the iPhone 13 "Mini" a chance (it's still larger than regular-sized phones a decade ago, wasn't removing the headphone jack an excuse to give phones more room to attach more technology to them?). Can Apple win a first-gen iPhone SE user? Here's what I think:,PROs,1- Battery Life. Needless to say, it's excellent. Let's see for how long that holds up.,2- Size. Even though is a tad bigger than the first-gen SE, it can fit in your pocket, you can hold it while running, though your grip isn't going to be as good, unless you have big hands.,3- Wireless charging. One of the best new features of phones today.,4- Screen real estate. A lot more than the older phones, even if it's just slightly bigger.,CONs,1- If the headphone jack was a dealbreaker then, this is not going to convert you. I miss it. I posted above why proprietary headphones are a bust, the alternatives are crappy cheap wireless headphones or a dongle.,2- Face ID. In the time of mask mandates, this technology has proven to be hilariously worse than TouchID. Basically useless and unpractical, unless you're driving without sunglasses.,3- Lightning jack. Apple seems to jump the gun when upgrading to technologies that don't improve their products, but they cling to the ones that make them money with their dear lives. Even their iPads have moved on to USB-C.,4- The protruding camera box. Hilariously bad design choice, but it forces you to buy a cover to level the phone on its back.,The verdict is, should you move on from your old, headphone-jack capable iPhone? The answer is, get a battery replacement. The only clear advantage of this new phone is the battery life. Everything else are needless and worse upgrades than the old iPhones.

I'm new to iPhone and 5G.,Pro for this Mini-13: It's small and lightweight.,Pro: It takes good photographs.,Pro: I can now Facetime w/my daughters (they're iPhone aficionados).,Con: I don't see any advantage of 5G (I understand that's not necessarily Apple's fault). If anything my connection at home is worse than it's ever been -- and I'm paying more for that!,Con: Placing the cursor is difficult, much more difficult than on my previous Androids (Kyocera & LG).,Con: I cannot set different volumes for my ringer and my notifications.,I'm putting up with the cons for now because I have no choice for the next two years. Thanks for reading.

Coming from a 1st gen SE, the improvements are very visible. It handles everything I throw at it. Never realized how dated the SE was until I got the 13 mini. However, I wouldn’t say it is overwhelmingly impressive.,Originally I wanted a 12 Pro or 13 Pro due to the higher RAM in those at 6GB. Had to settle for this mini because of inventory shortage. Used 12s exist but I won’t get something refurbished outside of Apple.,The form factor of the mini is perfect for me but having 4GB RAM in this mini is disappointing. Longevity concerns are there. Apple is good with RAM use but eventually it will be a thing. I’ve seen it happen in the past with iPads, iPods, and that SE. RAM matters if you don’t want to buy again for a long time.,Battery drain is not terrible but it is there. Definitely felt my SE was better with drain. Can’t imagine how bad the 12 mini was if this is improved from that. Regular 13 must be better here.,The lack of a charger is noticeable. Using old chargers are a bit slow. Would have been nice to have an actual decent power one with this.,Also lack of headphone port is an irritant. Got an adapter but, it’s a needless expense. Don’t like Bluetooth stuff. Had some in the past give me headaches when using. Don’t trust it.,Overall I like it. Probably get a solid 5+ years out of it which is the primary reason to go Apple. Better support. But, just kinda feel this 13 mini is a tad underwhelming. If you need this form factor, get it. But if you can go bigger, go Pro. Sadly the Pro colors are blech compared to the 12s but, specs will be better.

I've had an iPad Mini 4, 5 and now 6. I use them in the cockpit of a small plane, which is one thing Apple is now marketing the Mini 6 for. But I also use it for general tablet stuff; web browsing, watching YouTube, listening to music. I upgraded from the 5 to the 6 specifically for Pencil 2 support. The Mini 5 supports the first-gen Pencil, and while that was great as a first step towards going paperless in the cockpit for me, the way the Pencil 1 charges is just really an inconvenience for my use. I'd constantly get in the plane only to realize my Pencil is dead, and I'd have to just go back to paper anyway. I ended up just always carrying paper and a pen on me anyway, which kind of defeats the purpose of having the Pencil. So being able to have the Pencil 2 constantly stuck to the iPad and charging magnetically was enough in itself to get me to upgrade.,You'd normally expect that any upgraded tech device would have all the stuff you liked about the prior model, but just with more power, features and/or a more elegant design. In the case of the Mini 6, though, I feel like it may be one step forward, two steps back. I'm really happy with the Pencil 2 support but not really with anything else. I may actually be returning it; I'll update this review if I do.,First, jelly scroll is real. I'm always skeptical of complaints like this. They often start with one person who's either overly nitpicky or who just got a defective unit, and then they snowball as others with the same defect or a severe case of OCD write internet comments in agreement. But I was honestly shocked when I turned on my Mini 6, went to a random web page in Chrome, scrolled and saw the effect. It was much worse than I expected, and easily noticeable. It is difficult to believe this got past Apple's quality control.,In reading some other articles about this, it seems clear that Apple's not really lying when they say this is "normal LCD behavior", but the problem is that they've mounted the screen controller in the Mini 6 sideways. If you look at the Mini 5, and pretty much any other tablet, you do see some jelly scrolling in landscape orientation, but not in portrait orientation. The Mini 6 is the opposite; it jelly scrolls in portrait but not in landscape. So it is, oddly, a landscape tablet. The weird thing about it, though, is that the controls are not really set up for that orientation, and I sure don't normally use it that way. It's not an efficient way to read web pages; the only thing it's good for is watching videos, where jelly scrolling isn't an issue regardless of how the screen controller's mounted.,The screen is also slightly taller (or you could say "wider" if you consider it a landscape tablet), and that doesn't work well in portrait mode either. My Mini 5 shows 6 icons across and they are nicely spaced. The Mini 6, using the same settings (smaller icons), shows 5 icons across and they are weirdly bunched up in the middle. This could be fixed with an OS update but I'd never buy any product based on the promise of a future update. Also, it again is just a weird design decision from a company that's supposed to be all about design.,I compared the screen brightness of the two tablets as well and while they're close, the Mini 5 is very slightly brighter. Again, I made sure they had the same settings - max brightness, Night Shift off, and True Tone both on and off. The Mini 5 screen always wins by a hair.,Add to all that the removal of the headphone jack and I'd say that if you don't need Pencil 2 support, keep your Mini 5 or buy a refurbished one if you're in the market for your first Mini. Save yourself some money too. This was just not a very good update to the Mini line.,Personally, I just need to decide if the Pencil 2 support is enough to overcome all of the Mini 6's downsides. My only viable alternative if I do want the Pencil 2 is the iPad Air, which is $100 more expensive and bigger/heavier... not necessarily an asset in a small plane carrying two people. The iPad Pro also supports the Pencil 2 but it is larger still and even more expensive. It's a tough call for me, but I'd definitely say that most people should get either a Mini 5 (if you don't need the Pencil 2) or an Air (if you want the Pencil 2 and have the space for a larger tablet).

The new 6th Gen iPad Mini (2021) has several upgrades over the previous iPad Mini, and now looks more like a smaller version of the iPad Air.,Notable upgrades over previous version:,-Screen size: 8.3 in. liquid retina display, previous version was 7.9 in.,-A15 chip:  This is the latest Apple chip, previous version was A12,-Cameras: 12MP rear and 12MP front cameras, previous version was 8MP rear and 7MP front,-Redesigned like Air:  Slightly different shape, no home button, USB-C instead of lightning charger, fingerprint reader on side, volume controls on top, magnetic 2nd Gen Pencil charging on side.,There are also new Pink and Purple colors available, Starlight instead of Gold, and still Space Grey.,If you don't need a larger screen, this iPad Mini is a great option.  Now with the USB-C and  2nd Gen Pencil support like the iPad Air, combined with the A15 chip and Center Stage front cameras, this Mini has some of the best features of the other iPads.  It is a very capable device; it has the hardware to handle everything from drawing with the 2nd Gen Pencil, to watching movies, to gaming, to video calls.  With the latest chip and OS, this is as future-proof as you can get, so this device should last you a long time.,This could be worth upgrading from the previous iPad Mini, especially if you love the 2nd Gen Pencil.  For me, the USB-C and 2nd Gen Pencil support makes it worth the higher price.  The way the 2nd Gen Pencil just magnetically sticks to the side and charges is much easier than the 1st Gen Pencil.  The only thing I wish this Mini had was a 120 Hz refresh screen, but other than that it is just about perfect.  This is probably the most-value-for-money iPad at the moment, and is the one I'm using most often now because of the convenient size.

I've owned this ipad mini for all of 5 minutes and have come to the first Apple hurdle: No cable to connect it to my Apple desktop or Macbook. The cable they supply fits neither machine. Heck, it doesn't fit my iPhone either!,Which brings me to the gist of my review: I've been an Apple customer for probably close to 25 years but at the same time I purchased this ipad I also bought my first Android device (tablet) to begin the changeover. For the short term I'm a bit anchored to Apple through work (graphics) but find Apple products and policies so overbearing that I'm over the coolaid hype and have begun the switch back to Android.,For example; this cable that isn't supplied. Gotta buy more horribly overpriced/coolaid accompanying items.,Seriously Apple?,Or, wanting to play music in itunes that Apple - for whatever reason - feels like ghosting that day.,Or the inability to remove U2 music from my itunes. For over a decade. FFS apple, if I delete them 100x, I don't want them!,Or, wanting to download my photos and store on my external HD, in .jpg format - and not some Apple invented proprietary format.,Or, the never-ending parade of asking me for passwords. Accept it once, and that's my password until I say it needs to be changed. Not you.,Or, trying to charge/connect my device with a "non Apple authorized" cord. Sometimes it works, sometimes it works if I unlock my phone, and sometimes it won't work at all. Just depends. Really Apple?,Or, trying to get virtually ANY Garmin product to play nice with Apple:,Ride a bike and use a Garmin product? Problem.,Own a boat and use a Garmin product? Problem.,Own a motorcycle and use GPX files to navigate offroad? Problem.,The list goes on an on. Just one frustrating interface after another.,The hours of frustration that Apple has forced me to endure in the last few years are what's making me switch. This iPad will be phased out with the tablet over the coming year. My Macbook is a few years old and needs updating but won't be updated with a Mac product, and neither will the Imac or my iPhone. I'm just so over the frustration.,The good thing I guess is that I own a bunch of Apple stock. So all you 16-year old Coolaid drinkers will be helping me as I switch to Android.,Goodbye Apple. It's hasn't been fun.
