The new 3rd Generation Apple AirPods are simply incredible. They are comfortable, easy to use, and offer an unmatched quality of sound!,They arrived within 2 business days, and once I opened them and took out the earbuds, they automatically connected to my iPhone, which indicated on its screen the battery life of both of the AirPods and the charging case. There is a lightning charging cable included.,They aren’t completely noise cancelling like the AirPods Pro, but they offer a slew of incredible features—use of Siri, long battery life, incredible sound quality, in-call use, sweat and water resistance, and detectors and sensors for ease of use! The microphone is amazing—I’ve heard from many people that it sounds even better than my iPhones microphone while talking on the phone!,The instruction booklet is very helpful, but they are so easy to use that you probably won’t need to refer to it! Apple has left me completely satisfied, and you truly do get what you pay for when it comes to wireless headphones!

I love everything about my new Apple iPad Air except for it’s battery life. I do tech support and have been in the computer business for 26 years and as a hobbyist since 1976. and for about the last 9 years I have been doing remote support for mobile devices both Apple and Android. I have watched the two devices move closer and closer together as far as features. When iOS 14 came out and they made widgets available on iPhones, I thought Why didn't they do this for the iPad? Well, now they will be. It will be interesting to compare screens once they do. I also own a Samsung Tab S7+ both tablets are top quality.,One giant step backwards was removing the split screen keyboard option on the Air 4, and the Pros. I had to search for a 3rd part keyboard. Which on iOS there are not a lot of. Dumb move on an otherwise great device.

The rose gold color is fantastic. All of the case tones are beautiful and soft. Any choice will be a great option.,Battery life on the first day lasted over several hours of videos, gaming, general web browsing, managing my inbox, and setting up new apps.,Size is about the same as a spiral notebook. It weighs very little, but I put a very protective Valkit case on it which increased the weight quite a bit.,Screen is good, not amazing, but suits most average users’ needs.,Apple Pencil 2 support is a great feature and makes this iPad even more fun to use. There is basically no latency when drawing or writing- you won’t notice it if you haven’t used a pro model iPad or high end tablet.,Speakers are OK. I wish they had 4 speakers instead of 2, but I am most likely to use my headphones when watching videos, so it doesn’t matter much.,WiFi + Cellular is a must! Having GPS and cellular connectivity means you can use your iPad anywhere and for any purpose with ease. Most data plans for iPad are super cheap and easy to add to your phone plan. Just do it!,Amazon Warehouse Deals review:,This iPad was marked down significantly in price and marked as “Used - Very Good”. The description indicated that the iPad would be slightly scuffed and the packaging would be damaged.,I was willing to take the trade-off since it also included cellular and didn’t even cost as much as the base model.,What I received made me really happy! ipad had no damage and included a Paperlike screen protector already installed. The box was opened and resealed with tape, it had a dent on the front and a sticker. The contents were all there and properly packaged.  It was a great deal and I’d buy a AWD product again.

   I use it everyday! It doesn't freeze or overheat! It charges fast, it’s loud in sound and also light weight! I got the green color its so gorgeous!! I love this ipad so much and I'm honestly so happy i bought it because i tend to get indecisive lol.

Screen,I really love going through social media watching YouTube videos and texting, I’m texting way more than I did in the past 5 years and the onscreen keyboard is so great to use. One thing I do want to complain about is that the blue light that this tablet outputs must be very high because the day I started using this tablet I found it way harder to fall asleep. Be sure to turn on Night Shift to get some good hours of Zzzz. Besides that the screen is great and in my experience it’s the perfect size for using it as a tablet, if you’re going to use it more for a laptop get the big IPad Pro.,Battery,This is going to be short. The battery is very great, it has a 7606mAh battery and it goes for days without a charge. I don’t play any games on it but I do use it as a laptop for college and it still does very great. The 60Hz screen must really help battery life because this tablet with very heavy usage can go for about 3 days until it dies. If you are worried about battery life don’t be because it’s great.,Processing power,To help you understand this has the same A14 Bionic as the iPhone 12, it’s crazy fast. This will handle any game, college work, photo editing anything you can think of. It does only have 4GB of ram but it doesn’t seem to slow it down in any way. With the amount of power this thing has it will still be fast 3 years from now. To make this short I’m more worried about the world ending than this tablet being slow in the next few years.,Connectivity,Connecting to my iPhone XS was super easy and both work together so seamlessly like I can’t even explain it. I haven’t had any issues connecting to my speakers, keyboard, WiFi router, texting (just so you know your iPhone has to be on to be texting from your tablet), everything works great. I used to have issues with my S4 connecting to my speakers and issues connecting to my WiFi router with my laptops and it makes me very happy to see that so far I haven’t had any issues with this tablet.

When I opened the packaging everything was sealed, everything was there. The battery is good. The shade of green is super cute- like a pastel pistachio green. Takes decent photos. The sound is insanely loud. I got a paper-like screen protector to draw on so the screen doesn’t look as crisp as it does without it but I’m willing to make that trade for not scratching up the actual screen. Anyways if you’re an artist 10/10 recommend getting this bc it’s cheaper than the pro and I can do so much with it!!

TLDR: The so-called "File system" is a nightmare for Photographers.  If you are not willing to totally change your workflow for Ipad OS (which is not easy to do), Ipad is not for you. No matter how good the hardware is.,I have been a long-time Android user who also loves taking pictures using his DSLR. Last year I saw I pad air gaining popularity because it had a file system and USB c port.,The iPad air has a stellar screen, Fast processor, and guaranteed  4 years of support from apple. Seems like a no brainers for a photographer like me who wants to import photos, edit them and post them on social media. I was totally wrong :(.,The file system:,The camera roll (photo gallery) does NOT share same space with the file system at all. You will have to COPY the photos from external drive to internal memory, THEN save those images to Photos and ONLY then you are able to see those pictures in your Photos app.,External storage support using the USB c is trash. Some of my memory cards don't show up in the file system at all, I have to plug them back in multiple times to work.,The final nail in the coffin was when I was trying to import the RAW files to Photos . THE RAW FILES DIDN'T SHOW UP IN PHOTOS. They were perfectly saving into the photos app before..... but why not now?,OK you know what, may be it is my fault that I am using snapseed app for editing my photos, I should get an app that is MADE FOR IPAD. Guess what, there is no good photo editing app for Ipad unless you PAY for it. I am not a professional, I just need an app as good as snapseed on Ipad :( without paying for it.,MOST big-name social media apps DO NOT have a version that works on Ipad. The same version as phones but stretched out on IPads' beautiful screen with crappy resolution.,The Ipad is probably everything a long-time iPhone user needs but it falls short when some one like me comes in to do productivity tasks. Either do it the Ipad way or else.....,Apple will never make the Ipad OS better because it will eat up their Macbook sales. I also use a Macbook for work and it is far better than Ipad OS.  I know a lot of people will downvote this but I tried my best to like the Ipad and failed.

Remember when each new version of an Apple product used to be an improvement? those days are long gone. Each new iteration of the iPad is significantly worse than the last, with a frustrating lack of attention to basic problems that keep the OS in the dark ages. How do you screw up an on off button? Well in this case you make sure it won’t turn on when you press the on button.  Instead you have to hold it down for an indeterminate amount of time, and to turn it off you don’t just press the off button, you have to also press one of the volume buttons. Stupid. Even more frustrating, if your iPad is off (because presumably your battery is low) and you plug it in the power will just come on automatically and continue to drain your battery. Having your iPad plugged in while on will result in the need to keep it plugged in for a significant amount of time before it will become charged, if at all.  This is absolutely ridiculous and makes it almost impossible to keep a full charge on the device. The battery itself drains extremely quickly even when you turn off all of the obnoxious apple options, continuously interacting with the Internet, and Siri.  Unlike the OS for iPhone, there is no option to go into a low power mode. Moving apps on the home screen and organizing your contact is still extremely frustrating. Because they’ve gotten rid of the single button you cannot just simply return to the home screen, you were continuously trying to swipe up most of the time to no affect. To close apps is even worse you have to attempt multiple times to swipe up and hope that the various apps appear in front of you so that you can swipe yet again to turn them off. Of course this is all in an attempt to save battery life because the battery is so poor.  And because they’ve got rid of the central button and you were continuously swiping on everything your screen becomes disgustingly filled with fingerprints, grime, and dirt almost instantly.  Using a stylus is not any better as they don’t seem to have the technology right to make this an easy solution to the problem of a poorly designed tablet.  Of course the lack of a headphone jack is it an appalling omission as Apple has never been serious about quality Bluetooth and their headphones have been the most consistently avoided tech the last 20 years .  I seriously question whether anybody who designed this device has ever actually used it in a day today environment, as the developers are obviously ignorant of these obvious problems.  Apple seems to have no desire to make things better, only to clutter devices with features that become an onerous burden rather than solving problems for the user. This will definitely be my last iPad.

The battery is decent, I do use the iPad for a baby monitor and that kills the battery very quickly. Some of the iPad features are not working as well as I’d like. The screen freeze that prevents you from clicking out of apps works, I use to play movies for my kids without them going to other apps, but won’t let me get out of it without completely restarting the iPad. It’s nice overall but definitely not the best.

The Apple Airpods (3rd Generation) are the best Airpods Apple has made.  I purchased these for my niece as a Christmas present.  She told me that the sound quality and the bass is way better than the Airpods (2nd Generation).  She also told me that she likes the fact that these do not seal so tightly in her ears so they are a lot more comfortable to wear, and they still stay in her ears.  I like that they don't go inside the ear canal as this should help reduce the possibility of damage to her ears. She also said they are not as heavy, and the battery life is really good.

I didn't open the box or break the seal, but I was NOT able to register the AirPods or add an Apple Care+ Warranty plan. Apple couldn't recognize the serial number. The box looked exactly like the one that my wife recently purchased from Best Buy, but her serial number is recognized in the Apple system. I returned the item and going back to Best Buy to spend a few dollars more to get a genuine Apple product.,I also noticed today when I bought some at my local Best Buy. The AirPods that were sent to me via Amazon did NOT have the clear wrap on it.

I had a set of the first generation AirPods, and they fit my ear perfectly. I purchased the 3rd generation as a replacement (battery issue). First, they are much larger in your ear than the first generation. I don’t find them uncomfortable, but they don’t fit as far into my ear canal as the previous set. As a result, more outside noise gets in. They are great unless you have background noise. As for the sound, I find the overall quality of this pair better than the first. The full dynamic range is more crisp/clear and these make the first generation sound a little muddy. The primary reason I didn’t give 5 stars is since they don’t fit as snug, background noise gets in the way. Also, I have to push them in from time to time while moving around so they don’t fall out (never an issue with the first generation). Time will tell on battery life, but for now it’s great. I haven’t had a good use for the spatial audio yet, but it does work well. I expect gaming would be the best use.

The 3rd generation Apple Airpods are a major disappointment. The principal issue is that they are designed to lie limply on your earlobe rather than in the ear canal, as other earbuds are. The Airpods provide NO SOUND ISOLATION at all. None. Zilch. The result is that you can't hear anything coming out of these earbuds unless you're sitting in a quiet room, which is not what earbuds are for. Their purpose lies in their portability. Yet a soft breeze, to say nothing of city traffic or a subway ride, will overwhelm the audio from these cans. What's the point of headphones you can't hear? Good question.,When I listened in a quiet room just to make sure I wasn't going crazy, I found the audio quality decent, slightly improved over that off my other off-brand earbuds. But those cost one-third the price of the AirPods. (Oh, and they have sound isolation.) I should be getting much better audio quality at this price. Instead Apple has done what all the non-audio companies selling headphones are doing: boosting the bass and forgetting everything else. Listeners are too checked out to notice or care what they're hearing; all they can detect is bass. That's why every new product made by any company that isn't Bose, Sennheiser, or one of the other legacy brands is bass-forward. It's marketing, not sound. As a musician and careful listener, I'm the opposite of impressed.,I give the Airpods credit for superior internal mic'ing, which allows you to place calls more effectively than with other earbuds. My interlocutor was able to hear me relatively clearly using these earbuds, an improvement over the competition. There were still issues of wind noise and that "far-away" sound, however. Interference and distance are unavoidable with earbud mics, but some do better than others when it comes to filtering and signal processing in order to overcome environmental effects, and the Airpods do shine here.,The Airpods also pair seamlessly with my iPhone, the first time and every time. But this isn't anything to celebrate. It simply clarifies that Apple is trying to force us to buy their overpriced, underperforming audio products by boxing out competitors. Such seamless pairing should be possible with other products as well, but instead Apple uses proprietary technologies that mar the usability of other brands. Imagine if, back in the day, Sony's Discman or Walkman was only compatible with Sony's headphones, and every other brand required an adapter. That is what's happening here; only the details of the tech are different. This seamlessness is not a feather in the Airpods' cap. It's a powerplay by Apple, earth's richest company, trying to squelch the competition--including competition from companies that actually want to do audio the right way.,On the whole the 3rd-gen Airpods are not only useless, they are an indictment of Apple's corporate practices and, worse, a reflection of the sorry state of consumer audio in the era of low-fi streaming. It should not be possible to sell a product this faulty at a price point this high. If you want low-end earbuds, you can get them for $19.99 at CVS. If you want to spend $170, you can get excellent headphones from an audio company. Yet here we are, buying low-end earbuds for $170 from Apple.,I have returned mine, of course, and you should too.

Super disappointed cause as I stated prior these where supposed to be a Valentines Day gift. I’ve never had an issue like this on Amazon where you purchase something NEW and a seller sends you a used product.,Returning them, I recommend purchasing electronics from an actual retail store, or even online through a retailer don’t waste your time or money.

The Apple AirPods Max are everything you may have already heard. They’re fantastic and also wildly overpriced.,The design and build are fantastic. They look and feel significantly more expensive than my Bose. Drawing inspiration from both aviation headsets and recording studio units from the 50s, Apple has come up with a really iconic look. The Max is definitely heavier than the Bose I have but by no means intrinsically “heavy”.,The fit is good and AirPods are comfortable but it did take me some time to find the right position for me. Noise canceling is superior and invisible compared to any other type I have used. Apple has done well to avoid much ofthat sort of synthetic silence or hiss you get from noise cancelling. Passive mode is great and these work well talking on the phone also. The battery life is good and the two buttons on he right cup feel and work great.,Sound quality is excellent as expected with any ,used I have played, again leaning toward natural sound rather than boosted or over boosted bass levels. The Max excels greatly pairs to an Apple TV watching movies.,What isn’t so good?  They’re too hot to wear for workouts. I prefer something to let my ears breathe more when I’m exercising, so in-ear options may be a better choice. The case is a joke but not totally useless. The problem is while the case does protect the aluminum cups, it isn’t well made and does nothing to protect the comparatively more fragile parts of the earphones. No charger? No problem as have a  box full of USB and USB-C chargers already. Another small qualm is because of the case material, when you first unbox the Max, there is a very strong and unpleasant polymer type odor, but it goes away quickly.,Finally the biggest problem: the price. I think $350-400 is more reasonable. I had extra money I could afford to spend but I just don’t think $550 is realistic.  Apple aims to get you to spend as much as they can and from what I can see of demand and my own spending, they are winning people over.  Undoubtedly a cheaper variant will appear eventually and you may do better for your pocket book to wait it out.,I love these things. I won’t part with them. But they also cost too much. Your mileage may vary.

Great Sound Cancellation, Sound Quality and Fidelity, but completely stopped functioning after less than 3 weeks of moderate use two times over.,This happened with one pair, it started cutting out, then wouldn't turn on at all. Resetting to factory conditions and other troubleshooting did nothing to fix it, and then it wouldn't even initiate the reset process when prompted.,After making a request, they replaced it in a timely manner, which was appreciated, but then it happened again with the replacement pair after even less usage time. All while I was taking extra care to avoid all potential hazards and made sure to use it for even shorter periods than I had for the first pair. So I'm not convinced that it was the result of a mere fluke.,It was a great product, with great Bluetooth signal range, noise cancellation, and sound quality. It was even somewhat distressing to no longer have the blissful quiet they provided on demand. It would be well worth the price if it wasn't prone to breaking for no discernible reason within a month.

I will be comparing the APM with the Sony XM4's as I purchased and used both side-by-side.,The APM have incredible active noise cancellation (tested with airplane white noise on YouTube) and their transparency mode is incredible. I give them the edge on both fronts compared to the Sony's. I also think the handoff between multiple Apple devices is superior to the Sony's which can only pair to two devices at the same time. I also feel there is potential in the magnet APM cups that can be changed as desired. If you don't like the ones that come with the APM you could potentially purchase a 3rd party option of a different material.,I prefer the Sony's for sound quality. You can tweak the EQ to your liking with their app. With the APM you are stuck with their default sound signature or the terrible presets in iOS settings. The default APM sound is good but leaves a lot to be desired compared to the Sony's which literally lets you tweak it to how your ears desire. I am a bass-head and the APM bass simply lacking for rap and pop music (to my ears).,While I think the concept of the APM physical controls for volume and track selection is superior to Sony's touch controls for the same, the placement of these buttons on the top of the right cup is baffling. I'm confident most people are like myself and like to adjust their headphones by gripping the top and bottom of their respective ear cups. By doing so you will inevitably press on these buttons. The Sony's have two buttons located on the bottom side edge (on/off and a custom button that by defaults lets you toggle modes). Far better placement.,The 'smart case' is actually nothing but a sleeve that is rather ridiculous as it's required to properly turn off the headphones entirely. Why Apple opted for no on/off button is beyond me. The APM come with no cable to connect to airplane entertainment systems, no travel case, no ability to fold into a more compact size, and no charging brick. A $550 set of headphones should include a charging brick and nice travel case, don't you think??,The Sony's meanwhile have all the cables you could possibly need, fold into a compact size, and comes with a lovely hardshell case. It doesn't have a charging brick but it's also far less expensive compared to the APM.,Ah yes, price. At retail the APM are $550 and while the Sony's retail for $350, they can often be found brand new for $280, literally half the price.,So let's recap. APM have amazing ANC, transparency mode, mic for phone calls, the ability to swap out the ear cups, and flawlessly work with multiple Apple products.,The Sony's allow you to tweak the sound to your liking, are more comfortable by far to wear, an on/off button plus superior button placement, a hardshell case, fold into a compact size, include the necessary cables for travel, and cost half as much as the APM.

I had to think long and hard before spending $549 on over-ear headphones. I tried Beats, SONY XM4, and now AirPods Max. Beats were too heavy on the base, and SONY XM4 plastic design creaked too much when I would move my head, ruining the experience. AirPods Max premium build quality do not creak whatsoever, and offer the best sound quality of any headphone I've ever owned.,As for the $549 price tag... Apple are competing with professional headphones that cost upwards of $1000 (you can buy professional headphones that are easily $3000). In essence, you're getting the sound quality of a professional multi-thousand dollar headphone, for anywhere between one-half and one-fourth the price.,NOTE: if you do not have an iPhone, I'd recommend NOT buying these headphones, since you won't get all the benefits AirPods Max have to offer. If you JUST care about sound quality, and not spatial audio etc., and you why've an android, then by all means go ahead and pick these up.

Ok, I splurged on this. It was an impulse buy after I got my tax refund, I’m not gonna lie. My beats were all beat up, (I swear they make those things out spit and rubber bands), so I went for the next level “bougie” headset. I have to say, I’m NOT disappointed. The noise canceling is uncanny, I mean it’s magic! I’ve used the Bose flagship noise canceling headphones (forget the model name) and these are superior by far. The sound is also impressive, not quite as bass heavy as the Beat series, but way more balanced with more clarity + depth. The build quality is tight, not flimsy, and may actually hold up after a year or two of regular use (imagine that?) Also, I’m all Apple everything, so connectivity is a breeze.,Are they worth $500+ ? Meh… you can probably go much cheaper and get something comparable. But looking like a baller while sitting in economy plus, exit row with rose gold colored cans on your head? priceless…

After reading all the criticism of the included case, I was surprised to find that I really liked it. It's a well-designed, compact, silicone enclosure that you can slip the phones in and out of with ease. It even feels good to the touch. So, I suggest withholding judgement about the case until you try it.,Yes, the sound is fantastic. Best I've ever heard from headphones. Definite upgrade from my Bose QC 35's. Pretty heavy but very comfortable. I love the controls. Volume control is a knob you turn. Noise cancellation is amazingly good and easily controlled with another little knob, when you need to hear something in the real world.,If you have other Apple devices, the headphones pair with all of them when you sign on to one of them. After that, they just switch quietly, automatically, on their own, to whichever device you are using.,The charging input is Lightning and like the newest iPhones, the AirPods Max do not ship with a charger, but that's no big deal.  You can plug them into any Apple charger you already have or any charging USB outlet, for that matter, using the appropriate connector cable. They ship with a Lightning to USB-C cable which I use it to charge off the USB-C charger that came with my iPad Pro. There's no lady announcing battery levels, as with Bose phones--you must use battery readouts on your device. I use the large battery widget on my iPhone.

                ,
   Well I’m an Apple fanboy and I love their products. I’ve been waiting for a long time to purchase this Airpods Max cause Amazon has a great discount this Black Friday.,The sound quality is way better than my Beats Studio 3. It’s lightweight and very comfortable to wear. The noise cancellation is great.  And on top on that, it sync to all of my apple devices automatically just like the Airpods Pro.,Love it

i was so ready to return it primarily because it’s just way too expensive despite how seamless it connects to all my apple products. until i decided to watch something on apple tv, in this case “ice age” and used this headphones instead of my tv speaker. my jaw dropped. i was mind-blown! with spatial audio it felt like i was in a movie theater. it’s insane! absolutely amazed by what it could do. it was so immersive much more than when i was listening to music. of course, i ended up not returning it.

The good:,Headphones sound great. Pretty accurate, decent clarity, but a little lacking in the bass (for my taste). They're super comfortable, look good, feel good, and the sound cancelling is great. They obviously work well with apple devices (which as with most somewhat lacking apple products is a big selling point). Nice feature for the replaceable ear cups. Overall, a good listening experience.,The bad:,Price is pretty high - but somewhat in-line with similar quality and sounding headphones in their class. The 'case' is absolutely stupid, and mind-bogglingly horrible. It's unfortunate that the headphones don't collapse to a more travel-friendly form factor. As with many Apple Products the over-simplification of the headphones is a little meh - it'd be nice to actually be able to turn them off.  Charging a modern product with a lightning cable is so dumb, it's a port that should have died years ago. For a set of expensive headphones that should last a long time - they should have went with usb-c for sure - and having wireless charging would be good. Everyone has been speculating the iPhone (the last remaining device that uses the antiquated port) would ditch the lightning port for years now. If the iPhone finally ditches it next year, then these headphones will be the only thing that anyone has with that stupid cable. Macbooks, iPads, and every other current tech product in the universe uses usb-c, so it'd be great to only have to lug around a single cable.

I love music ... and I love headphones almost as much.  I won't say how many pairs I have, but rest assured the number is high.  Long story short, the AirPods Max are far and away my favorite.  I've used them consistently since the day they arrived.  I was impressed on day one and am still impressed months later.  The sound quality and noise cancellation are both incredible.  Beyond that Apple has incorporated some great features.,Having said that, I have two complaints.  The first is the case - it's a joke.  If you plan to travel with these headphones you really need to purchase a different case that actually offers a bit of protection.  Second, the headphones don't come with the required accessories.  I'm specifically referring to the power adaptor and 3.5mm cord.  Both have to be purchased separately which is kind of crazy at the price Apple is charging for these headphones.  These two items are definitely disappointing, but they're not necessarily deal-breakers.,If you can get past these oddities the headphones themselves are amazing and have proven to be a real winner.  I remain extremely satisfied and would buy them again given the opportunity.

The Apple Watch is different from my old Fitbit. I’m getting used to the larger size. I like the customizable face and what you can access from it. I like that I can answer calls and texts messages from it if I’m away from my phone.,Wish the battery lasted more than a day. Oh well.

I went from a very old apple watch to this one so there was like fireworks and stuff going off in my head !!  It's a great watch for the price !!  All new fabulous features, much longer battery life and it even does an EKG !!!  No heart problems here according to my watch, thank goodness !

The 7 is easier to use, if that’s even possible and the battery life is much much better than my 3. If you’re a first time buyer or looking to upgrade I highly suggest this one!

This is a considerable upgrade from my previous Apple Watch (Series 3). I decided to get the 41 mm instead of the 45 mm, and I am delighted with the watch's size. The display is vibrant, and it does a great job of logging my workouts. I would recommend this watch.

So now I guess I have to spend yet more money to get the wall charger! or I just may return it.

I wasn’t sure what I was getting myself into. Being that Im over 50 I was somewhat intimidated by the iPad. But this thing is so user friendly. Not very difficult to navigate. The camera quality is excellent. My 2 daughters have been using it and each of them want one as well.

Great device. The battery life is outstanding. The speed is surprising. The speakers are better than usable, they’re enjoyable to use. They only things I think I don’t like are the fingerprint scanner and the aspect ratio of the screen. I’ve mostly used cheaper android tablets before getting this tablet, so any comparison to android would not be fair. When I say cheaper, I mean just over the $200 range. That is why my expectations were a bit lower going into this one as well. They tended to have a nice screen but would be laggy and the speakers would be almost useless. This iPad stands out in stark contrast.,Oh, another con is that there seems to be no oleophobic coating on the screen. It holds fingerprints like a magnet. Cameras are also not good, but I tend to not use them, so they don’t bother me.

Ok, I’ve had the new iPad Air 4 less than 24 hours, but it’s awesome. The size is slightly larger, but it really makes a difference. The audio is fantastic for streaming music and movies. Can’t really say about battery life as I haven’t used that much so far, but it charges quickly. If you’re interested in an upgrade Air 4 will be enough to stream, play casual games, and internet searches. It is compatible with 2nd generation Apple pen and keyboard. However I haven’t invested in either one yet. May not be the most helpful review, but it is enthusiastic.

The whole reason I purchased this iPad was to do music, but if the headphone jack won't work, it's of no use to me. I will not be spending another $200 on wireless headphones that I don't care for. Either apple is making junk inferior products OR what the seller is giving you is not an actual 100% brand new apple ipad. It came with a 90 warranty and ONE month after it expired it is not working anymore at all. Can not get it to shutdown and only shows a plain white screen with small grids. Looked up troubleshooting online for that problem and apple recommendation is to bring it or ship it to them, costing ME almost as much as the ipad cost originally. I upgraded to the iPad Air 4th generation from an Air 2 which just wasn’t able to run newer photo editing or music software. My focus is mostly on music and the Air 4 runs circles around the Air 2. Running multiple synths through GarageBand and Cubasis would choke the Air 2 at three or four virtual synths. I stopped at eight virtual synths and a dozen or so audio tracks on the Air four.,The stats are readily available so I’ll skip that and talk about features I like.,First, it’s nice to have USB C as I plan to use a drive to shuttle stems (audio tracks) to my music computer. Previously it involved using the cloud with an app and downloading from there. Doing it locally is vastly easier. I’d imagine photography and visual arts people would appreciate the choice.,The user interface literally feel better. Others have said they feel “one” with the glass and they aren’t lying. It is a unique feature and makes touch a more enjoyable experience.,The extra screen space is nice too.,The Air 4 is heavier and is thicker than the Air 2. To me, it feels more substantial.,I purchased an inexpensive case/keyboard and it enhances the experience. Again, this is an individual’s choice. The one I purchased has an magnetic keybed that is detachable. This is good because it allows for easier use of portrait constrained apps. If the cost of Apple’s cases weren’t substantially more expensive $150 - $350 I might have considered it but with the combined cost we are in computer or Chromebook territory.,If you use other Apple devices you probably don’t need to be talked into purchasing a new iPad. I spent a few days looking at what was available and honestly, the Air 4 is a good value for what it does and the ever expanding App Library which is a very strong sales point. My Air 2 is still useful. I’m typing on it now. It is my social media/internet tablet. I’ve been using it many years with virtually no problem beyond wear and tear I’ve put on it. It is a mid priced tablet, and I’m not saying it isn’t a substantial chunk of money, but comparing features it is more than competitive and Android still has a way to go to compete which isn’t a shot at Android or fans of it. For my needs the Air 4 is exactly what I hoped it would be.

This iPad is great if you’re willing to spend more money. Compared to the 9th generation iPad it is a nice upgrade. The speakers are on both sides instead of just one which makes watching videos much better. The screen resolution is pretty much the same but this iPad has a Liquid Retina display instead of just a Retina display but most people might not be able to tell the difference. There is 4gbs Of ram compared to the 3gbs in the 9th gen which makes this one better at saving apps in the background so you don’t need to reload them as much. The Touch ID in the power button is fast and accurate, I was a bit worried it wouldn’t be as good as the home button one but it is pretty much the same. If you care about cameras this iPad has a better back camera but a worse front camera compared to the 9th gen. This iPad has Bluetooth 5.0 instead of 4.2 like the 9th gen this makes it better if you’re going to use multiple Bluetooth devices like a keyboard and earbuds. The A14 chip is very fast and can handle pretty much everything you would want to do. The display is also laminated so it is better for drawing. Overall it is a really good device, I mainly use it for school and entertainment and it has worked well. The multitask feature is very good and it does not slow down at all when using it.

The shape of the AirPods are a little uncomfortable and after only 2 weeks from receiving them the left AirPod starting to make a crackling noise as if the speaker was blown. Was never used over half volume and never dropped. I was able to get a replacement but my hopes aren’t too high on the quality. Sound was great, while it lasted. I decided to upgrade after using the generation 2 AirPods for a year. I work outside on equipment so they are used anywhere from 4-10 hours a day. I still prefer the generation 2 AirPods that have held up very well considering what I put them through. Also don’t like they went away with being able to customize one AirPods to pause and the other to change music. So far what these offer does not match the price tag.

Got a pair of these Gen3 for each of my 20/21 sons and they HATE HATE HATE them!!!  Much fatter design n more awkward in the ears and fall out CONSTANTLY!  So pissed that I spent the money when I just could have gotten new Gen2s instead. Can’t comment on sound quality bc they don’t stay in the ears long enough to use them. Fail.

What I like most about these are the size. The weight is different than with the AirPods Pro and the 2nd generation. My issue with headphones are they slip out super easily. These actually stay in my ear and I can jump up and down and they won’t fall out. These are definitely worth the money to me.,So far the only issue I have is when I eat something they fall out. Which isn’t a bad thing.

This is in comparison to my 1st gen AirPods.,Pros:,Better looking in ear,Way better sound quality,Great battery life,Cons:,A little uncomfortable after a long period of time.,I’m not a fan of the “pinch” features vs the tap features the previous models had.,I bought these specifically because I did not want the noise cancellation. Solid 4/5 just because they do feel a little uncomfortable after having them in for a while. They fit a lot different than the 1st gens. The best way to explain it is they kind of sit in your ear as opposed to going inside of your ear.,If you have smaller ears these definitely will not fit you and will be extremely uncomfortable for you. I’d stick with the pros or the older model.

I’ve had my first gen AirPods for 3 years, using them almost daily. LOVE them.  Battery is depleting now which is to be expected.  Only last about 1.5 hours now instead of 5 hours.  Was excited about these new AirPods and the shorter sticks so ordered them.  Apple reconfigured these apparently to work with more people’s ears.  But now they don’t fit me.  :(. They are too big.  Fell out on first time use.  If I jam them into my ears, they may hold for 10-15 minutes and start falling out again.,So if you’re in the category of people who could never used Apple earbuds, these may have been configured for you and I recommend trying them.  If the regular AirPods fit well, they may not work for you.,No question about quality, it’s the same (to me) good Apple quality for the last 10 or more years.,Good luck.

The new airpods 3 compared to my old gen one airpods sound divine, especially the base. The spatial audio is really cool too, though I haven't found much use for it in daily podcast and video streaming unless I look for it specifically. As for the noise cancellation, don't buy these if you actually need this feature. The good thing is if you like listening to music in an office setting but still need to be aware of people talking to you occasionally, you will have no trouble hearing them while on low to mid volumes. Also the battery is amazing. I don't have to worry about charging the case for days while using them constantly for hours during that time.

The audio quality on these is amazing, they look great, and the microphone reportedly sounds good, but...,* They are surprisingly heavy.  Unlike, say, the PLG Focus, you'll have difficulty wearing these for extended periods of time without fatigue, which is a problem if, like me, you bought them to work from home.,* The model I bought has software and hardware issues.  It won't reliably connect to, stay connected to, or switch between your iPhone, iMac, laptop, or iPad.  The button you press to switch between audio modes worked properly at first, but now won't respond.  Could be a first generation issue (something you didn't worry about with Apple hardware, once upon a time).,Would I buy it again?  Yes, based on one feature: a great microphone.  I've tried a dozen different premium headsets over the years, and this is the only one with which people I talk to on the phone consistently say sounds as good as speaking directly into my iPhone.,But I'd pay even more for a model that was lighter and less buggy.

So I mainly purchased these to watch tv on my apple tv at night. I have a pair of the apple airpod pro's also. So which do I like the best. Unfortunately not these. The sound is not the best. I expect a lot for 500 plus dollars. These don't give the sound when listening to music that I want. They slip on my head constantly. The buttons on the top are constantly in the way. I am always touching them when I try to adjust the headphones. Which then turn things on or off. I made all the adjustments recommended by youtubers and they still don't have the sound of the airpod pro's. The case is stupid. There I said it. They should have not provided a case at all. It gives zero protection for these 500 dollar item. Also why should I purchase a hard case and other protection items for this. They should provide it since they charge so much for the item. Still not sure if I am going to send back or keep. I am leaning on returning them. I am just not impressed with this item. Also apple why should I research on how to use your items? think about giving directions for use.

I've owned several headphones and before trying these AirPods Max, my favorite pair was the Bose Quiet Comport 35 II. These are simply phenomenal!!!,Price Wise...I've heard a people say the AirPods Max are so expensive, but are they really? I will expound.,Last I checked a person pretty much still gets what a person pays for....meaning the AirPod Max is the best and has even been compared to $800 Beoplay H9/H95 headphones in several reviews. So when compared to an $800 pair of headphones...then it's about value...where else can people by an $800 sounding headphone that is as classy for $465 to $550?,It's NEVER just one thing with Apple...it is about the quantitative all encompassing details that add up to even more and more value. Just like Steve used to say, Making things easy is hard...an that costs something. If a person cannot see the details, they don't have to buy it...no body is twisting anyone's arms. People buy because of two things, they either Trust you and/or your product, OR they see the Value in you and/or your product.,Anyway hope that might provoke some food for thought or perhaps a different perspective...and hope that this might help others out there. :-)

I’ll start this by saying I also have the Sony WH1000-XM4’s, and these absolutely crush them in every aspect. I am selling my XM4’s after only a week of using the AirPods Max.,PROS:,Sound is subjective, but in my opinion these are far superior in sound quality to any wireless headphones I have ever tried. It’s bright, colorful, and has no distortion even at full volume. 10/10.,The noise cancellation is... unbelievable? I put them on and immediately sucked into space. I don’t know how they pulled it off. The transparency mode is also crazy, it really just sounds like you aren’t wearing them. Truly a marvel.,Battery life is good, lasts me two days of wearing them all day while I work. 20 hours feels accurate.,Just like the AirPods Pro, the Bluetooth is better than any I have tried. I can move through my entire apartment without losing connection, and the auto switching changes the game.,CONS:,The case is... terrible . Such a bad choice from Apple, and it’s pretty astounding since the rest of the headphones are the best and seem very well thought out. It’s hard to get them in and out of without bumping the cups together and making me afraid I will scratch them. It provides almost no protection for the headphones. I have elected to get a third party case that will put them in low power mode, but I am hoping Apple will address this in a software update and allow me to turn them off.,If you can deal with a poorly thought out case, get these. I have no regrets.

I absolutely love these!! One note on sound, I am running the latest FW (3E756) and using the Headphone Accommodations setting on “balanced” mode and using an iPhone 12 Pro Max and iPad Pro with the latest os’s. I was on the hate train until I actually tried these and fell in love with the intensely immersive sound stage. The sound profile is perfect for me and for the first time in a long time, I actually get completely lost in the music. I’ve had very high end open back wired cans and much prefer the sound profile in these APM’s. Pure enjoyment!!,These are very comfortable for my ears and do not have any issues with the weight. I’ve had the sony mx4’s and for me, there is absolutely no comparison between the two. The APM’s are in a completely different ballpark in terms of both sound quality and build. Take a look at the tear down and comparison between the APM’s, the Sony’s and the Bose on ifixit.com.,The noise canceling and transparency modes are unmatched. Spatial audio is very cool and adds a new depth and experience. Apparently it will be available to use with all streaming services with iOS 15.,Highly recommended if you’re in the Apple ecosystem.

I was excited to get the AirPods Max. And will say that the battery life was great. Noise cancellation was superb — tested them while running a table saw. And audio were top notch. Check. Check. Check.,However, I sent them back for two reasons. 1. The way the noise cancellation is tuned gave a subtle/weird sound effect. 2. (Most importantly) these things were uncomfortable - very heavy. As a result I think these guys were designed to really clamp on your head to stay put — causing more discomfort. That alone would cause me to not wear these in the long run — so back they went.,Bonus reason: for that price these things should come with a real case. The thing they came in was not up to par with Apple’s typical level of quality and feature expectations.,I’ll stick with my Harman Kardon headphones and hope the second gen is lighter and the case better.

I wish I tried these before spending $4,000 on a pair of Sennheiser HD800S headphones and an HDV 820 amp to drive them. the HD800S and hdv820 is arguably the world’s best headphone setup, but these Apple headphones sound just as good or better for most top 40 music. For classical, the Sennheiser has a slight edge, and they can get much louder than the AirPods. However if given the choice again I would have saved the $4k and only bought these Airpods. Before I bought the HD800S I tried every type of super premium headphones in search of the best ones. The HD800S was by far the most comfortable with the best sound, that is until I tried AirPods. They are equally if not slightly more comfortable and I’m not tethered to an amp.

I purchased these with a stipend, so luckily I didn't have to pay out of pocket. Otherwise, I would've been satisfied with the Sony XM4's (especially when they're on sale for $250 at the time of writing this).,I had originally purchased all 3 of the major noise cancelling competitors to see which one I liked best. The Bose QC45's that just released were a major disappointment to me, getting distorted as the volume increased and lacking any character in the EQ profile. They were super light and comfortable, but didn't sound nearly as good as I was hoping. Those were returned.,I purchased the Sony XM4's and was very impressed. With punchy bass and clean delivery of vocals and high end details, for the price, I definitely wouldn't regret buying those out of pocket. Even then, there wasn't as much detail and I still found myself wishing something else was there to wow me.,I put the AirPods Max on, and I was BLOWN AWAY. The quality of sound out of a bluetooth, noise cancelling pair of headphones was incredible. I had heard things in songs I've listened to for years that I'd never noticed before. Everything is perfectly balanced, nothing is overpowering or muddy. I was hoping to have the best of both hifi headphones with the convenience of a bluetooth set, and I think this is as close as I can get.,The one thing that is the most annoying is the wired solution, which doesn't even work if the headphones die. As a video editor, this is beyond frustrating.,Other than that, I will continue to proudly consider myself an Apple fanboy, and one who is suckered into spending money on good marketing and beautifully designed products.

I have Sony and Bose headphones and to me these are more balanced than either the XM4 and the QC35. Are they perfect? No. Are they worth the $500+? No. I would easily recommend these if they were priced around the Sony’s and Bose’s headphones which are these biggest competitors. Pros and cons time!,Pros:,Balanced sound,Metal construction,Physical buttons for controls,Stylish,Comfortable,One of the best ANC on the market,Good microphones for phone calls and video chat,Pairs flawlessly with your Apple products,Cons:,The price,Can be a little heavy due to the metal casing,The “headphone case”,No off button,No charging mount,Lightning port,As you can see, the pros out way the cons. In my opinion, I can’t justify the price. I even bought these when they were $50 off. I think the biggest issue people are going to have is the “case” and no power button.,The headphones will go into sleep mode to conserve power. In order to do that, you have to put these in the case that doesn’t offer much protection. However, this also allows the headphones to easily connect to whatever Apple device you have then paired to when you’re ready to use them. If you want to take these for traveling you will have to buy a third party case.,With that said, these are my favorite set of headphones. This is coming from a long time Bose fan. They sound absolutely fantastic. I use them all the time at home for music and videos. The metal casing makes them durable. The trade off being they can be heavy, and will take some time to get use to.,Physical buttons makes these superior to other headphones out there with touch controls. You have two buttons. The Digital Crown which controls the volume and play and stop. The second button controls the ANC. The noice cancel on these are also fantastic. It cancel out most sounds. They do have some issues canceling out high pitched noises like a blender. With that said, they do tone down those higher frequencies.,It’s just a shame these are so expensive. I’d recommend them if you have the money to spend and are a big Apple fan. If you don’t have the money the. Sony’s XM4 and Bose’s QC35 are great alternatives.

Since I mostly work from home and listen to music when I'm not on the phone I use several bluetooth ear pods including AirPod Pros.,The Max version has always intrigued me but I have quite a few over ear headphones so until they went on sale there was nothing compelling me to purchase them.,I've had them long enough to break in the drivers to some degree.  Yes like most dynamic headphones these need to be broken in for 20 to 50 hours before they can be judged for sound quality.,1.  I'm a headphone guy so sound quality is my first priority.  This is an excellent headphone.  They blow away my bluetooth Sennheisers on sound quality.  They even compete with some wired headphones.  They may not reach the level of my Grado 325's but they are much more comfortable.  My Focal Clears, which incidentally match well with the output voltage of my iPhone, are superior but are much more expensive.  And wired.  BTW you can't get Lossless audio through Bluetooth so a wired headphone has that advantage.  And you can't talk through the Clears.  My wired Sennheisers don't really have the output levels to match an iPhone so they are not in the consideration.  These have a wide range sonically and reproduce all kinds of music well.  And unlike some Beats models they are not bass heavy.  I think they work best with Spatial Audio off.  iMy only complaint is that the midlevel sound stage is a bit compressed regardless of volume.  Apple did their home work in designing these headphones.  I'd go so far to say that you will not find another headphone wired or not that has as good as sound for the money.,2.  Comfort/Fit.  One goes with the other.  The head band is comfortable for my large head and does not squeeze my ears.  The ear pad material is not what I'd like but it is surprisingly comfortable.  Typical of any headphones they are best used without glasses for maximum comfortable. If you use glasses put the pads on your ears with the glasses on for maximum comfort.  I do not notice any weight - these are much lighter than most wired headphones.  The ear space fits my large ears although ideally a couple of extra mm's would be better.,3.  They connect easily once you go through the initial connection procedure.  Most importantly they have excellent battery life.  They have double or more battery life than Pros.  Put them in the case when you are through with them for the day as it is the only way they turn off.  You will otherwise lose battery life as they are otherwise constantly scanning for possible bluetooth targets.  The case is not great but it works well for being put into a bag or backpack.  Generally they do a good job of picking up your voice in telephone or FaceTime mode.,4.  They are an excellent value.  Usually a substantial discount means that there is a newer model is coming out.  My research suggests that is not the case.  There is likely to be a newer model of the Pros coming out which explains their greater discount.,I am very pleased with these headphones and I think that you will be equally as pleased.

I upgraded to these after my dog ate my old ones, and I don’t like in-ear buds, so my comparison is between these and gen 2.,Pros: sound quality, sound adjustment with video (I’m sure there’s a term for it, but I’m talking about how it sounds like the noise is coming from behind you if you face away from your device—that blew my mind),Cons: I can’t get them to fit in my ear comfortably, like they’re too large or misshapen and always feel like they’re going to fall out. Despite the improvements, the discomfort was too much, and I bought a new gen 2 pair about 3 weeks after buying these.

I got my AirPod's yesterday in the mail love how they feel comfortable in your ears, and the cool features that they offer is pretty cool. I was at work listing to music with the right AirPod in my ear while walking around work my phone kept going off, with a notification "Find My phone" which I had no clue why it kept going off? Until I open my phone with my work address displaying saying that I left m airpod behind. That's so cool which will help me find them if I ever loose them or if someone try's to steal them.

I used to have the airpod pros but after my right airpod began to frequently not charge I decided to get a new pair. When I looked I found myself surprised to see airpod 3rd generations so I figured why not give them a try.,I have found that so far they are much less snug than my pros were and have hardly even close to the noise canceling ability of them, but they do sound good and I got some ear loops to fix the fall out problem.,I think they aren’t a bad update from the pros or 2nd gens if you’re a die hard AirPods fan

I upgraded from AirPods second generation because they stopped charging. I loved my AirPods 2nd Generation- mostly because they fit super well!,I have sensitive ears so the AirPod Pro was not an option.,These don’t fit like the originals. They fall out super easy for me.,However the battery life is great and I don’t have any connection issues across my phone and MacBooks so that a plus.,I wouldn’t ever run or workout with these because of the fit but they are ok for working.

I have used these headphones for several weeks now and I really like them. They sound great, the battery last a really long time, and they will read you an incoming text from an iPhone and tell you who is calling. My only complaint is they are a little big for my ears and sometimes fall out when I working but when one of them falls out the music or audio book will stop playing so you know one of them fell out. I have had many apple products and have only had one that let me down. I can’t complain.

First things first, these are 100% the real things. Bought mine brand new and the packaging was fine. Not sure what was wrong with everyone else’s. I guess Amazon hates you.,Look and features : 10/10,By far these are my favorite looking AirPods. Didn’t quite like the longer stems on the Gen1 and Gen2s but I love the stems on these. I really like the squeeze to skip/play instead of the tapping on the older models. Leads to much more purposeful actions. The water and sweat resistance is nice as well. Dropped one in the snow and still worked fine. The new case is about the size as the older ones and just disappears in your pocket. Wireless  charging is cool but I don’t have a wireless charger so can’t say much on it.,Sound: 7/10,These are definitely an upgrade in sound compared the the 1s and 2s. But doesn’t mean they’re perfect. The spatial audio feature is cool and all but gets annoying so I had it turned off. The base is alright for wireless earbuds. But…. The mids and highs not so much. Any song that has a lot of mids, you know, what most instruments are, they get this weird background buzz. It’s not super loud but it’s loud enough to annoying as all hell. They also don’t perfectly seal with your ears (I’ll get to that later) leading to noise bleed and mediocre noise cancellation.,Fit: 0/10,These things are huge. By no means do I have small ears, I would say they are average. But boy oh boy do these not fit. A few of my friends tried them and they don’t fit any of us. They are a pain to get in and once they’re in you cannot walk around. The movement is just too much for them and they fall out. Even sitting still these feel like they want to come out. If you have to use the small or medium sized tips on other earbuds DO NOT buy these. But, if you have freakishly large ears, still don’t buy them.,For an extra $20 ish buy the pros, trust me.

I bought this knowing exactly what it was capable of and not capable of as well as features it did not have. Sound quality could be better but works fine for casual music listening. Not as good as I hoped it would be for capturing my voice clearly for the other side to understand my speech well. Still fine. The biggest gripe I have is that these don’t fit my ears well and eventually pop out. I have not had this problem with gen 2 or the pro. Perhaps it’s just me. I may need to look for a silicone sleeve.

Airpods just falls off during an extensive exercise. Skin-detect sensor doesn't work for me. We should have an option to have either pods to turn off auto ear detection, not just in both of them. Everytime i take out one of my pods, music just pause and had to play it again. It just annoying in my opinion. Still preferred Airpods pro than this.

I wanted these AirPods for work so i can listen to music while I work. These were so terrible they didn’t fit in my ears, they kept falling out and hurt so bad when I would try to readjust them. I admit, based on reviews, I expected these to sound magical. I wasn't blown away, though...to me, they sounded good, not amazing. It seemed like the mids were scooped, which is not my preference. Wish this was something I could tweak like other headphones out there. I also found the headphones did not have a high enough max volume..this was frustrating.  I think the design and build quality are superb, the tactile feel of the headphones is nice, and the iOS/MacOS integration is flawless. I have AirPods pros and Bose QC35s at home and I decided to get the AirPods Max, as the Pros have been wonderful. I have a iPhone, iPad, and MBP. All work wonderfully with both the Bose and the Pros. The Max has been a nightmare. Connecting it to the iPhone was seamless, just like AirPods and AirPods Pro, however the audio was dropping in and out multiple times over the first few hours with the MBP. I then took a call with them and the device kept dropping from the iPhone every few minutes. Multiple "Can you hear me now" statements and I switched back to the AirPods Pro and it worked just fine.,I have to believe I got a faulty device, but for the price, that's just unacceptable quality control. I returned them and will continue using my AirPods Pro and QC35s. Maybe will give the Max another chance in a future revision.

I haven't put it through the test, but i suspect this will not last 20 days even if you don't use it. It drains even in the bra case.,Well. I hope this somewhat gives you an idea.

You want audiophile quality sound without all the BS?  Buy these and forget about needing any more gear.  No cables, no amps, no A/D converters, no tower speakers, no subwoofers, nothing.  I own very high end systems with top-rated versions of all of the above and I can tell you that AirPods Max cans sound as good as anything you can buy. They have one small flaw (beside the stupid name) and that is that the included case/bikini underwear is pathetic and storing them elsewhere uncovers the fact that auto device switching is not perfect which can consequently cause them to lose charge when they keep turning on and off.  A good-old hardware on-off switch would be the solution.

The sound and the anc qualities are good. However, the product is not at all wearable. The clamping pressure is enormous, making it difficult to wear them all day. There is also no protective case for the product. You will have to buy a separate case for it even though you already paid $600.

This review is very specific to my case, however, I felt as though others out there may face similar.  So here goes.,I wear glasses, and I hardly shave.  My stubbles make wearing the headphones a bit more scratchy feeling.  My Bose QC35 II's have that fake leather, and is more comfortable IMHO.  That wasn't the deal breaker, but what was, was my glasses.  I wear glasses every day and that they a bit wider to fit my face right.  Officially, they're 58x19X150mm.  With that said, I could never really get a good adjustment that felt comfortable to me.  It felt like the pressure was more towards the top part of the ear pieces.  I'd expand the headband to have the ear cups sit a bit lower and it be a bit better for a bit, but the pressure on my frames as well as the temple and temple tips was just too much.,Alas I've returned them.  The noise cancellation was quite a bit better than my Bose, as well as the Airpod Pros.  The sound quality was quite amazing, and I've come to now realize that my Bose are bass heavy, to which I'm not a fan of any longer.,Cheers!

This is a beefy boy. But it carries the weight very well. It's more comfortable than leather headphones - probably because my ears don't sweat as bad.,I was really hoping to wear these all day every day because they really are so good - but the lack of water stops me from trying.,The Transparency mode is really transparent and almost perfected.,The ANC blocks out even the local crowded friday-night bar noise to a whimper.,Music quality is on point.,There is just one issue that I've run into that I never really ran into with any other headphones - condensation. After about an hour I found "mist" lining below the ear cups. For the breathable fabric, I surprised by this. I'm sure the engineers knew of the condensation being an issue since it's not leather - like every other headphone. Together with a lack of any water resistance, It's worrying to even wear these headphones.,Why the 1 star? The glaring design issue with water build up over time and no resistance to the water build up. I can't use these headphones at all. They're an expensive door stop.

I purchased a used AirPods 3rd generation,  the AirPods are in good shape as described, but when I try to connect it I found it still linked to the previous owner's iCloud account. Apparently, the previous owner didn't remove it from the iCloud account before returning to Amazon and Amazon didn't check it before reselling it to customers. A Amazon associate I chatted with was funny, he told me to contact Apple (why? I have no idea, it is a Amazon problem not a Apple problem). But I did, I reached out to Apple customer service, Apple was not able to help because Amazon invoice didn't provide the serial number, I couldn't approve if that was a used AirPods I actually bought from Amazon. The other Amazon Customer service representative was good, she fully understood the issue, she refunded me the full amount and asked me to dispose the AirPods whatever I want.

So far this is a nice product for me. It fits my ears very well. Sound is great. I can use it with multiple devices which I absolutely love. Absolutely most uncomfortable things I’ve ever put in my ears. These things are bulbous to say the least. I put them in and within a few minutes my ears began to hurt. I took them back out, and a while later I tried again, adjusting the positioning. Well.. they still hurt. When I made any sort of facial expression they loosened up. After they hurt on my third try a while later I gave up. I have no idea why Apple would make these things so massive. I compared to my AirPods 2 and they seem to be twice the size. It works for some people but I’m so disappointed.

I’m a an avid AirPods user, and LOVE them completely, I wear at least one most of the day and they never fall out of my ears or become uncomfortable, in fact I forget I’m even wearing them. I was excited to see the new features offered on the new AirPods 3 and I ordered a pair. Unfortunately the new design won’t stay in my ears, a problem I’ve never had with Apple earbuds or previous AirPods. So, I returned them and will be sticking with my AirPods 2 for now. I’m hesitant to try the AirPods Pro because I’ve had issues in the past with in-canal tips becoming painful, but I guess If I want the added features I may have to give in and try them. I think I might wait and see what the next generation of AirPods Pro are like though. If the newly designed shape will stay in your ears, they are awesome, and well worth purchasing. Good luck!

First of all, these sound FANTASTIC!! Way overpriced is what I thought initially but when I heard the sound (and noise cancellation) they are well above and beyond the less expensive Bluetooth headphones. Another big benefit is how easily they switch between and connect to distant Apple products (perfect if you have multiple).,The BIG DOWNSIDE,They make my head itch. Not sure what’s going on but I’ve had the Sony XM 3 for a couple years with no problem. These Apple ones make my head itchy within the first week and a couple of hours of wearing.,Additionally, they had a very strong chemical odor when you open the box, unlike any other Apple (or other brand) product I’ve ever purchased. It smelled like one of those cancer chemicals (I am forgetting the name right now). The smell did go away after a few days of airing them out.,However, my head still itches every time I wear it. I don’t have that problem with the Sony ones.,I am super bummed as the sound quality and ease of connectivity make these totally worth it. I hope Apple looks into this issue and see what is causing these chemical smells etc

I was skeptical that the AirPods Max were just another device that was the epitome of the "Apple tax" - A regular device that worked well enough, but was EXTRA expensive just due to fit/finish/materials and not really a differentiated experience.,Let me start by saying: I was WRONG.,The AirPods Max are BY FAR the best sounding headphones I've used (not withstanding professional studio monitors I've used that I'd NEVER use on the street). They are absolutely above the hype - They perform amazingly and integrate as flawlessly with my Apple devices as their more diminutive in-ear counterparts.,They're not only extremely well constructed, but have the best noise cancellation I've experienced - This is likely a combination of excellent ANC parameters and algorithms and great ear cushion design. Speaking of those cushions, they are the ONLY over-ear headphones I can wear all day and take seamless calls from!,Excellent apple integration, modular consumable parts (magnetically replaceable ear cushions should be a STANDARD on high-end cans!) and excellent performance mean these are now my go-to when using my Apple devices...

I bought these and they did not connect to my iphone automatically. After playing around with it they connected but it was intermittment. Then I put them on for a while and they felt heavy so I decided to return them. Had to talk with a supervisor and he said, "Well you can *request a return but that doesn't mean you'll get a return." No lies-- this is Amazon Customer Service. I am baffled. Things are changing.

I don't know why apple, of all companies, can't figure out how to make ear cups that don't smash glasses into your head. These even have removable ear cups. So stupid, and so intensely uncomfortable. I know there are replacement ear cups that are supposed to be mildly better, but they make the sound worse. Why buy $600 headphones that need to be modified so they don't leave glasses imprints on your skull. The Sony's don't sound quite as good, but are half the price and can be worn comfortably with glasses for hours.

Real Talk - these are NOT "Metal Beats Studios" or whatever. These are 100% Apple. As such, they are designed and meant to be paired with Apple products. You do that, you are good to go.,What you do not get: A charger. It uses the same one your iPhone or any other Apple Lightening thing you may have does. It comes with a cable. Mine is still in the box; I just charge from my computer. Apparently, this is a problem. I don't get it :),What you DO get:,-  A *very* immersive, *very isolated* soundstage. The Noise Cancellation is so insane, it is near "witchcraft" levels. It's legit. :),- 'Super Hearing' with Transparency Mode: If you have used this with AirPods Pro and where like "yeah, ok, this works"...this is more like "Yeah. I can hear *everything* SUPER CLEARLY. Stop breathing so loud"-levels and the "mix in" is really balanced with audio you may be listening to.,- Spacial Audio on these things is hard to describe without sounding overly hyperbolic. The directionality is much more dialed in than the AP Pros, the "behind you" is really great. I wish it worked on my Mac tho. Maybe in the future.,The build on these is like...I have zero concern I will break them. Ever. I believe they could seriously injure someone if swung hard enough. Seriously.,A lot of time and testing was put into the mechanisms, resistance of sliding, the sockets for the ear cups that rotate, very smoothly, but also have a firm, strong spring action for grip against your head.,Now...there *is* a problem. If you wear glasses, they will start to irritate a little from pushing against the side of your head. it is not the ear cups, which are borderline pillows. it is the pressure/pressing of the arms of glasses into your head. Be aware of this.,Handoff works great, call quality is great, very nice audio sep, highs do not sound sibilant unless they *actually are*, the bass is clear, not "muddy" and you *will* be hearing what you've been missing with these, like other headphones in this range. That's the really cool thing about these; hearing 'ghost notes' you never had before, studio sounds, etc. These really bring that stuff out.,I am ambivalent about the case/'case' controversy. They don't, heh...these things don't need a case. Heh.,They are not inexpensive. They also...are not "cheap". There's a lot of "sour grapes" out there around these. They are indeed, at least twice as good as AirPod pros...so if you like those or the Beats sport  wireless earbuds...and like music and stuff...you'll enjoy them. If you have to "save up" for them...worth it.

Noise cancellation and noise play through is incredible. They have the best sound for Bluetooth headphones - only comparable to Bluetooth headphones costing $850 or more (I have listened to multiple examples). Good separation of instruments and could hear finer detail than my previous Beats headphones. Good audiophile headphones can cost more than $5,000 and also require equally expensive extra equipment to work and are tethered. For Bluetooth headphones, these have great sound and separation. I signed up for Apple Music which is recommended for these headphones giving you the full benefit of their capabilities for music. They work flawlessly in the Apple ecosystem going seamlessly from one device to another for example if you get a phone call and will automatically pause things like a YouTube video if you adjust the headphones or temporarily take them off. If you are using them for editing video then it is recommended that you purchase the $35 cord because Bluetooth gives a very slight delay when you are editing video. Lossless sounds really good but to get the full benefit of Lossless you need the cord and a DAC (digital audio converter).  The Dolby Atmos and Spatial Audio work great without a cord and many of the apps for streaming like Apple TV, Disney and Paramount have spatial audio. Watching Picard was fantastic. I have a noisy air conditioner in my work room and it cuts it out completely making it easy to concentrate.

I’ve had Bose headphones for years; great sound and very comfortable. I guess I kind of fell for the hype of Apple so I caved and bought a set of the AirPods Max. First, I’m really not impressed with the sound quality, especially the bass. Second, the location of the controls on the headphones is prone to accidental use when adjusting the position of the headphones. Third, they aren’t super-comfortable on the ears, which is where Bose shines. Last, I’m not sure what to say about the “case” other than I can’t decide if it looks like a purse or a bra. At least that made me laugh. I have not used them yet for a call, so that may sway my opinion. But, as of now, For $429, they are just ok.

I feel like I just moved from Standard Definition TV to HD. You can simply hear everything better; each instrument is more distinctive. I notice riffs that previously were just part of the background; I can hear a singer being close-mic’d; the pop of a drum or pluck of a string is more realistic. I don’t want to give false expectations, but at the same time, my music listening experience has genuinely, discernibly changed.,I upgraded from the Bang & Olufsen H8. It was an on-ear headphone, so the sound isolation is an extraordinary leap for me. My husband got annoyed within 5 minutes of me taking these out of the box, since he was talking and I couldn’t even tell. If you haven’t experienced Transparency Mode before, though, it’s the perfect antidote, when you want it.

I am astonished by the sound quality and noise cancelling of these headphones. I've been in the Pro Audio industry for 30 years and have had access to all the best brands of sound equipment. I've never heard headphones that sound this good. The voicing of them is simply perfect in my opinion, any music or movies I listened to sounded better than anything else I've ever listened on.,I recently used them on a flight across the country and the noise cancelling pretty much took care of all the engine noise. Now I will not fly without them! Highly recommended!

First pair had issues with the right side ~ loud swirling wind sound. Apple couldn’t fix it. I returned those and bought a pair on Amazon because they delivered faster. Second pair sucks for a completely different reason. They constantly drop Bluetooth connection. They randomly make a loud, deafening static noise. These SUCK. It’s a shame. I like the sound quality when it works but ‘when it works’ is not a phrase that should be used with $600 headphones. After these experiences, I made the mistake of buying a thrid pair. These stopped working after 1 month. Apple won't accept the return. THIS PRODUCT SUCKS!,What happened to Apple? They used to be consistently excellent. Now their products are hit and miss.

Have had it for about a month. The charger stopped working after it fell from average-ish height (my desk). However, the watch itself is great. I use it for my runs, the phone feature when I’m driving, and the health app. The best feature is the find my iPhone. I use it daily and it saves me the time of logging into the app. I rate it 4.5/5 because of the fragile charger.
