Okay, I've been an Android fan since, well, since the very beginning...I still am if I'm being honest. I have also spent a ridiculously large amount of $$ on smart watches over the years starting with the original Moto 360 (anyone remember that flat tire?). It LOOKED cool, especially that round face, but performance-wise, well, it was kinda terrible. The battery life was insultingly horrible (it would lose 7% in the ten minute drive to work while just sitting on my wrist doing nothing). But the potential was there. In finally switched to Samsung's Tizen at the introduction of the Gear S2. What a great watch that was. I went on to the Gear S3, the Gear Sport, the Galaxy Watch, the GW3 and then I heard the news: Samsung was going back to Wear OS. This disappointed me greatly. Over the years I have owned well over a dozen watches utilizing Wear OS (or Android Wear before that) and while I loved a lot about many of them, they ALL suffered from the stuttering and glitching that plagues essentially ALL Wear OS devices. Some have managed to work around that to produce the best version they possibly can (TicWatch Pro 3 and the Oppo Watch are just 2 examples) but each had at least something that just didn't work properly - and I don't blame either manufacturer for this. It's an ongoing problem with Wear OS itself. Slowly, I began to warm to the idea that maybe, just MAYBE Samsung will make it work the way it was always supposed to work. So, I bought the Galaxy Watch 4.,Did Samsung fix Wear OS? In a word: NO. It still suffers from glitches, hiccups and stuttering and apps not opening properly and/or timely. At times it works just great (which is more often than not, but still...), I have a fairly expensive watch that ruins what otherwise ought to be a smoother experience than what I'm getting. My Galaxy Watch 3 runs fantastic (it runs on TIzen software and not Wear OS) and honestly, I have had zero issues with it since I got it over a year ago, nor any with my previous Tizen watches including the Gear S2, S3, Gear Sport and original Galaxy Watch. I have had intermittent issues with the GW4 since the day I brought it home. To be fair, I have heard many people who claim that their Watch 4's have run flawlessly since they bought theirs...but I cannot speak to their experience, only the one I've had - but I brought it up to be fair.,I have done a LOT of research regarding all different kinds of smart watches, and you know what you almost never hear from the majority of apple watch owners? You don't hear about not getting a notification, or stuttering and glitches here and there. Sure, I'm sure they exist, but the overwhelming majority generally say the same thing: the watch JUST WORKS. Honestly, that is all I really care about. Does it do what it claims and does it do it consistently? From an Android Fanboy, I can say this without reservation: the apple watch works and does so CONSISTENTLY. I simply cannot say that about my GW4 or any other Wear OS device I have used over the last 6-8 years.,Okay, now why did I switch? Well, when I heard that the apple watch could be used without an iPhone, it really caught my attention. Seriously, an apple watch that can be set up so the user does not need an iPhone?? Well that's just what I wanted to hear. The truth is, once the watch is set up with "Family Setup" as long as it's an LTE model watch, you do not need to have it paired with an iPhone AT ALL...however (and this is a biggie) - you STILL need an iPhone to set it up initially. That sucked. But - I have enough friends with iPhone's that I took the plunge anyway.,The watch looks phenomenal BTW. I got the blue model and that new watch face that takes advantage of the larger screen is fantastic. Since this is my very first apple watch, I can't speak to how well it compares to earlier models, so I'm sorry about that. Honestly however, having not used a previous model before, I just don't see that there is a difference that is noticeable when compared to my friends who have earlier model apple watches. The major thing I like is exactly what I wanted most: a watch that is reliable. It took a bit of getting used to because I have been so familiar with Wear OS and Tizen watches for so long, but it isn't difficult, just takes a little time, that's all. I haven't always liked the apple rectangular shape...but slowly, it grew on me. It was always made really well, of that there has never been any doubt, but the series 7 is just great to look at.,The one thing keeping my review from 5 to only 4 stars was the pretty HUGE omission of the charging block. As you've no doubt gathered by now, I'm a android guy and always have been. My last 4 phones have all used USB-C chargers...but none of them came with blocks that the USB-C cord went into, they all had the USB-C port on only ONE end, not both. It's fair to assume the majority of apple users do not own one of these, either. Meaning, it's an unnecessary EXTRA expense you absolutely MUST make in order to even be able to use your watch - unless you have a charger from a previous apple watch which you can still use, but you won't be able to take advantage of the faster charging time. For what apple is charging for this watch, leaving this out is nothing shy of a ginormous cash grab on their part, and it's rather blatant and disappointing. Seriously guys, this is simple greed...and if anyone at their HQ bothers to read any of these reviews will note that there are quite a few upset genuine apple fanatics who really are quite upset by this same situation, so I am definitely NOT alone here. Wise up apple or you'll force longtime fans into the arms of Wear OS simply to make a statement.,With that said, the watch operates extraordinarily well. I have seen zero hiccups that I see each time I turned on my Galaxy Watch 4 (seriously, EVERY time I turn it on, I get a notification that tells me I have voice mail, but when I check, there is nothing there - literally EVERY SINGLE TIME I turn the watch on. After 3 months...it got old...and now it simply makes me mad). I've always heard of the great haptics on apple devices and now I know what they mean. Samsung does a pretty good job as well on their watches, don't get me wrong, but these are just, well, better. It's hard to describe unless you've actually worn one to feel the difference. My TicWatch Pro 3 is actually a pretty good Wear OS watch, it really is...however, the haptics are so friggin' anemic I miss 90% of my notification vibrations due to the poor haptic engine it has. (this is an issue with hundreds of thousands of other TicWatch Pro 3 owners...it's on many online threads if you're curious) That isn't the case here with the series 7. I get ALL my notifications and in a timely manner and that on-screen keyboard with swipe-like ability is fantastic. It's not as good as the Google keyboard, but it isn't far behind...and for quick text input, especially if you're in a loud environment where you cannot use voice dictation, or you're in a quiet place or you simply don't want people around you to hear what you're replying, this is a wonderful tool and it works pretty great. Kudos to apple for adding it. I want to mention the haptic engine again...it's actually quite impressive. It vibrates in a totally different manner than ALL other smart watches I've ever owned. It works beautifully and it is hard to miss a notification due to it's efficiency. I swear, if my TicWatch had a decent haptic engine and better music-transfer capability, I may never have even considered getting the apple watch at all.,This the only smartwatch besides Samsung to make transferring music to your watch pretty seamless. OR SO I THOUGHT. I tried almost a dozen different programs supposedly designed to help convert my mp3's to easily transfer to my phone and then onto my watch. Almost every one would cap you at transferring 10 songs per day ONLY - unless you paid money. Even iTunes was a problem saying that I had to change this setting on my phone in order to transfer music...yet no matter how often I changed the setting, it still said I needed to do the same thing again. I deleted iTunes and re-downloaded it and tried again. Nope. Same issue. I finally discovered a program called, "SynciOS" which allowed me to transfer music in a pretty intuitive manner and do it ridiculously quick. Not sure why it took so long to be able to do something so simple, but sheesh, this was essentially the only thing that really frustrated me regarding my series 7 watch. Samsung makes this process STUPID EASY to do and sorry apple fans, is FAR SUPERIOR to how apple does it. All other Wear OS watches are no better at making this an easy process and in fact, can make it even more difficult.,I love how on my hikes, while listening to music on my watch, I'll get updates every mile I've reached. This is another great feature...but its one that is done better with the Galaxy Watches. The Original GW and the GW3 and GW4 all give you this same information but goes a few steps further. Samsung tells you when you've reached that mile, but also tells you how many steps you've taken to get there AND your heart rate. It only takes 3-4 extra seconds and it works great. The difference between Tizen and Wear OS however is that with TIzen the music would halt while the watch reads out that info thru the bluetooth earbuds, while Wear OS it just slightly lowers the volume of music and tells you the information. Apple lowers the music volume much lower which makes hearing your metrics much easier, but still, the more information the better as far as I'm concerned. Yesterday I wore both my GW3 and the apple watch and they each marked every mile within probably 4-5 seconds of one another - or roughly 15-20 feet difference, which says they both were pretty spot-on for how they measured distance. They both were within about 7 steps of each other as well and heart rate were off by 1 or 2 beats per minute. That tells me either they are both accurate, or both are off by roughly the same amount. There may be a few workout routines that apple doesn't cover which Samsung does and vice versa, but they do all the one's I personally use regularly and that's what counts as far as I'm concerned. Great implementation, too.,All in all, you've made this Android user a convert. Though, I still prefer using my Samsung phone. Sorry guys.,***UPDATE***,Battery life compared to my GW4 is simply astonishing - especially considering how much people whine about it online. Case in point: yesterday I braved the snow and 15 degree temps and walked the 5 miles home from work for my exercise. I wore both my Galaxy Watch 4 and apple watch 7. Keep in mind before I left, I topped off my GW4 til it was at 100%, something I could not do with my apple watch since I do not have a spare charger at work like I do with my Samsung watches, which seem to need it more often. I will stipulate that after a few weeks using my GW4 the battery life improved significantly as it "learned" my habits and adjusted accordingly. I used GPS on both to keep track of my walk, and listened to music downloaded to both watches and switched from one to the other exactly at the half-way point to make it fair. By the time I reached home, my GW4 was down to 61%. Now keep in mind I had been using my apple watch since 5am that morning and wasn't able to charge it before leaving for home. When I hit home my apple watch 7 was still at 79%. That is astonishing to me...and an enormously HUGE difference. I have suspected the battery life was better, but not by THAT much. I just looked it up, and the 45mm apple Watch 7 has a battery size of 309 mAh, while the GW4 has a battery size of 361 mAh. Sorry, but this is a GINORMOUS apple win here. It seems every other review I read about the newest apple watch, one of the chief complaints is battery life, but when compared to the GW4, I cannot help but be happy with it's performance so far. After having used the apple watch for over a week, using the GW4 reminded me (again) that Wear OS just isn't quite there yet. The crazy glitches that plague this system, the incessant notification of voicemail that is NEVER there 100% of the time whenever I turn the watch off and turn it back on again, the notification that my watch is playing media that isn't there, or that it's paired with a kindle that I have never paired it with, the slowness of opening apps and closing them again, the problem of pulling down the settings menu and how it works about half the time I try to pull it down, or scroll up working only part of the time, or how I close all apps only to discover some still open - apps I've never tried to open since the day I bought my watch...the list goes on and on. You know what glitches I've had with the apple watch? NONE. Seriously. I haven't had one single hiccup since I turned this device on. I truly wished this were not the case with my Samsung. The honest truth is I wouldn't even have an apple watch were it not for my sour experience with the newest Galaxy Watch. I still hope that a future update will correct most of these problems, and if so, I will be thrilled to see them implemented and will gladly state so. Problem is, I don't think this is Samsung's problem, it's an issue with Wear OS and Samsung can only do so much to correct it. I DO find it interesting that my older TicWatch Pro 3 has shown far fewer issues and glitches than the GW4 in pretty much every situation...so maybe its a combination of Wear OS and Samsung's version of Wear OS 3.0. Either way, I've been very disappointed in my experience and wish that they had never switched from Tizen in the first place. Oh well. Time will tell if Wear OS can correct these issues or not.,The body composition feature is cool on the GW4. I really thought it would be more useful, though. I suppose it can be, but - for me at least - it simply hasn't been something that I've been able to get any kind of genuine use out of. Reportedly it can actually measure your blood pressure...but on a watch? I honestly cannot see how accurate that could be using any kind of method the way the watch is set up. Every reputable medical site I have looked at says the tech is far too new and simply isn't capable - yet anyway - of accurately being able to measure blood pressure monitoring. Kudos to Samsung for initiating it, but at this point, I wouldn't put a whole lot of stock on accuracy.,Charging...so, since this is my first apple watch, I can't compare it's supposedly 33% faster charging over previous models...but I WILL say it's faster than the Galaxy Watch 4, 3, Original Galaxy Watch etc. and my TicWatch Pro 3...however, I have an Oppo Watch (which was clearly a ripoff of the apple watch design, but in their defense, they did a STELLAR job with it), now that watch charges FAST. Exactly how much faster, I cannot say for certain, but let's just say all of those other models I mentioned pale in comparison. I just find it absurd that apple did not include a charging block. An utterly imbecilic decision.

I expected the latest watch to work seamlessly with the latest iPhone.  This is the latest watch.  I have the latest iPhone.,I'm in recovery from two episodes of a dangerous heart arrhythmia and my exercise program consists of approximately 1 hour moderately intense walks each day.  At minimum, I wanted the watch to count steps, maybe measure distance as well, and measure and keep track of my heart rate.  I also expected to be able to access this information fairly easily and when I wanted to on my iPhone as well as on the watch.,Apple buried the pedometer if it has one, and if it has one, you can't put it on the watch face I just spent a long time selecting as the one that I liked.  Apparently Apple restricts third parties from creating useful watch faces, so there aren't that many, and there isn't one I could put what I wanted on.,I installed a pedometer app.  I bought the watch having been assured by the salesman that this watch had or this watch even was a pedometer.  What am I doing installing a pedometer app?  This seemed like buying an iPhone and having to install a phone app.  If you know the watch OS, I hope it wouldn't take you that long to set this up just the way you want it, but I didn't have the patience.  I think I got the number of steps to display but then there wasn't a place to put the heart rate.  I expected less hassle for this simple function.,I opened the iPhone Watch app.  I'm sure there is a way to get it out of the Settings screen, but at this point, as I was about to refresh my perception of how this app wasn't that easy to use, I can't get it to do anything except alter various settings.  I can't back out of the Settings into the program itself.  I've only been using computers since 1982 or so, when I studied assembly language on a machine with 1K Ram and cassette tape instead of a hard drive, so it could be that I'm not capable of figuring out how to operate the easy to use Apple software interface.,I even have an Apple Watch for Dummies book, the latest edition.  I ended up looking online for solutions to problems as they came up because for me the book was full of a lot of tips and info except no info on the particular problem, whatever it was, that I had.,Apple doesn't even consider the type of exercise that I am doing at the moment, i.e. fairly gentle walking coming back from a serious heart issue, as exercise.  So they program their software out of the box to ignore the type of walking I do, so people say.  Maybe the watch can be tweaked or if I muttered the right incantation it might decide my walks are exercise,  but as I looked for info on how to make the watch display information about my proposed walks, the first warnings I ran into were that walks are not exercise in the Apple ecosystem unless they are of a certain intensity.  I don't know because I couldn't set up the watch well enough to even take it for a walk before I gave up and told my wife, who gave it to me as a present, that I was going to send it back.,The screen is beautiful.  The 45mm watch seems too big and bulky for me and I am 6 foot 1 inch with big hands.  The aesthetically appealing watch faces are the least customizable.  I made sure to turn the alarm off but it went off at 6:30 am anyway, and it would not manually stop sounding off every few minutes after that.  Etc.  I'm sure I could have found some setting other than alarm OFF that would have made the alarm not be set to go off tomorrow morning, but...

As already posted in previous reviews, this watch doesn’t come with the usb c brick that you need to charge it, so buy yourself one when you order your new watch. I already had one because I recently bought an iPhone 13 pro. That and the shorter battery life of this watch are the only drawbacks. You’re going to have to charge this watch every 24 hours. That being said, it’s a wonderful watch. It came in sealed, Apple packaging. The watch box was sealed on both ends. I mention this because of a few other reviews that complain of unsealed packaging and missing items. It has many features and I love that the health app integrates with the watch and you can view all of the data collected by the watch there. I ordered and received the 41mm. I’m a woman and I find that an adequate size for my wrist and I’m actually glad that I didn’t get the 45mm because it would have been too big and I’m not a dainty female with a small wrist. It has a lot of apps available and I took about a third of them off and that made the ones I wanted easier to view. It has a lot of watch faces to choose from and there are watch face apps available as well. I would have preferred a different color but with all of the watch bands available to choose from and different colors of hard screen protectors out there, it really didn’t matter and it’s a great price. I did purchase the offered insurance for $79 as well. All in all, it’s a great watch. The last comment I’d make is that something as basic as a wall charger that’s required to charge the product that you’ve just spent several hundred $$ on, should include it. Are you listening Apple? Probably not, oh well.

É exatamente o que você viu até agora. Vídeo, foto, podcast, se alguém falou sobre esse macbook falou bem, e muito bem. Então já vou aos pormenores de antemão:,1. Ele é pesado. Uma coisa feita com essa carcaça belíssima, esse corpo perfeito, espaçoso do jeito que é, mesmo cabendo em um envelope de 23x30cm, não tem jeito, vai ser pesado.,2. É pontudo! Hahahaha, se alguém já segurou um iphone12 sabe o desconforto que é apertar ele ou ficar muito tempo na mão sem capinha, isso é muito estranho, mas mesmo com os cantos arredondados se você pretende usar ele no seu colo, vai se incomodar com a carcaça de traços bem definidos.,3. Essa ventuinha está quebrada. Sim! Impressionante, só dá pra saber que a ventuinha dele está funcionando quando você passa o dedo no corpo dele e seu dedo treme levemente, ao invés de derrapar. Nunca vi isso em toda a minha vida, realmente, fiquei besta.,4. Vem com uma base de 225gb de memória livre, na versão com 256gb.,5. A bateria não vai acabar, não adianta. Ela não acaba mesmo não, fizeram alguma mágica aqui. Eu to a dois dias, cerca de 11h usando desde a última carga completa, já fiz de um tudo aqui, até testei mineirar bitcoin com um programa em python. Pois é, a bateria segue firme. Agora fazem 23h, to com ele ligado desde as 15:30 por aí, caiu de 63% pra 20%. Nada mais a declarar.,6. Essa tela é surreal, muito adaptativa, mesmo! Meus olhos agradecem.,7. Esquenta sim ok! Mas só quando eu instalei um monte de programa um atrás do outro. Fora isso, ficou normal, e ele esquenta apenas acima da tecla esc, até o meio da touch bar, em nenhum outro lugar além desse. (acho que o chip fica ali).,8. Acabou, acho que isso é tudo o que eu nunca vi ninguém falar nos vídeos. Se você está pensando em comprar ele, compre-o, pretendo ficar com essa máquina por 10 anos, e acho que ficarei, assim como fiquei 11 anos com meu mac mini.,p.s. Ao vendedor, VOCÊ É DEMAIS! ENVIOU EMBALADO EM 3 METROS DE PLASTICO BOLHA, EU TE AMO <3

O MacBook Pro M1 é realmente tudo que falam: bateria com muita durabilidade, ótima usabilidade do sistema operacional, diversas funcionalidade que aumentam a produtividade, sem falar do design que é muito moderno e minimalista. Sobre a compra, foi uma ótima experiência. O vendedor foi atencioso, respondeu todas minhas perguntas e fez o envio com muita rapidez. Recebi o produto muito antes do prazo. Satisfeito!
Chegou rápido, lacrado na caixa, com nota fiscal original e garantia Apple ainda não ativada.

O Macbook pro M1 é INCRÍVEL, é um computador pequeno, com uma capacidade e desempenho de gigante. Ele é caro? Sim, mas vale cada centavo, pq o bicho é ótimo!,A iiStore entregou muito antes do prazo, com nota fiscal na caixa e eu tinha pedido no chat e eles me mandaram, logo depois que enviaram o pedido para entrega. Foram atenciosos e responderam todos os meus chats, da um medinho pq ele esta num valor muito mais baixo, comparado com outras lojas, mas é original e todo perfeitinho.,A tomada veio padrão americano, mas se vc tiver aqueles benjamin ou tomadas antigas em casa, da pra usar normalmente.,Estou totalmente satisfeito, eu nunca usei um produto da Apple e realmente é tudo aquilo que escutamos por aí, é um produto premium!

Hello. I’ve been eying the Series 7 for awhile as I had a Series 5 for a year and a half so I finally upgraded. I enjoy the slightly bigger screen, and brighter dispay along with better charging speeds and being able to use my old case and bands is a big plus in my book. To me it’s not much of an upgrade but you’re coming from a Series 3 and below then the upgrades will be major. People that complain about not having a charging brick in the box need to read the description as the description clearly says it doesn’t come with one so why complain about something that you should’ve known from the get go? They should do better research on what they buy next time and plus if you bought a new smart phone or even tablet within the last few years you should have a spare USB C charging brick laying around if not just suck it up and buy one Apple doesn’t include one so it can save on waste and declutters their packaging. The USB C Apple Watch cable allows the Series 7 to charge faster so I rather have a cable that allows me to charge my watch faster just in case if I forget to charge my watch or if I’m having a jam packed day ahead of me and need to charge it as much as I can so I can either get my day started or continue my day.

The screen alone beats all else. Once somebody gets to see the screen of the watch, the thirst is filled. The biggest feature is the screen of the watch. I picked  it up frequently to look at it and then put it away.

I have given this a lower rating of 2 because of Apple's stupidity. The watch itself is fine and should be rated higher. However, on the 7-series and on the latest iPad's, Apple has changed the charging cord on both ends. Both the insert connector to the power source and the connector to the watch (iPad) are different from previous versions and are not compatible with previous chargers. The power source can no longer be a USB port as the connector doesn't fit. And old charging cords cannot be used as they don't fit the iWatch or the iPad. This means you have to have double sets of chargers around, including automobile charges It is very annoying and irritating. Why did Apple do this?,In addition, I unplug the charger from my iPad at my own peril. When I reconnect it it doesn't always start charging. I have to fiddle with the connections on both ends, and even the AC adapter until it starts charging. This makes me leery about removing the charger to take the iPad elsewhere. It is not the cords or AC adapter as two sets do the same thing.,Is it just me or do others feel that Apple has gone downhill since Steve Jobs is not longer there.

So this is my first fitness tracker / smart watch. In fact its my first watch of any kind for a few years. I tried the cellular version and then returned it a few weeks ago for the GPS only version. Primary goal of the cellular was to free myself from carrying my phone whilst going running. too many subscription based apps, however, made this impractical, so the data plan wasn't really of much use. Plus it chews through more battery (more on that later). So yeah I think the tech ability  is finally here but Apple's ecosystem isn't very friendly to bundling your own playlists, so I continue to run with my phone AND watch AND bt headphones. Boo. Friggin. Who.,I am guessing the white band of the Starlight model probably turns a lot of people off, but you should know that bands are really easy to change, and cheap on the after market. I love the look of the starlight watch frame with a colored band. it gives the watch both the ability to be uniquely fun but can also have a more conservative look with a gun metal grey band.,The touch features are fantastic, as are the health features like vital signs. I've compared them to a real pulse oximeter and the o2 readouts are within 1% every time. Even the EKG sinus rhythm appears quite similar to a 12 lead. Remember, though, that this feature will not reliably detect (rule out) a heart attack.,Usability is quite good, also. the mini keyboard is surprisingly easy to use. Sure its not your phone, but it gets the job done. Voice to text is great and I find myself using that more than the keyboard. After about a week it primarily becomes just a time piece on your wrist as the novelty wears off, but appreciable features include the ability to glance at texts without pulling out my phone, and the flashlight feature is very handy as well.,there are a number of plastic/rubber covers on the market. I bought a two pack for use when i'll be out in the yard or an area where the watch may see more abuse. its more difficult to apply than changing the bands, which must come off to apply a protective cover. The screen naturally looses a small degree of touch sensitivity but is still quite usable. Mostly I go about my business without the cover. the 7 purportedly has a more durable screen and in a few months of use now I've yet to scratch it.,My biggest complaint, other than the music options for going running, is the battery life. I find myself charging it two or three times a day. Not that it needs that many top offs, but I don't like seeing any battery dip below 50%. the nice thing is that the charge is quite quick and painless with the so-called hockey puck. I can't imagine how frustrated I'd be with previous generations that don't charge as quickly as the 7.,if you have small wrists go for the 41mm. Medium and large will probably be happier with the 45mm.

I got this as a gift from my wife for my birthday and I love it!  I had an Apple Watch (series 2) that stopped working a bit over a year ago. My wife got me this to replace it.,The jump from series 2 to 7 was dramatic!  I did research to find out exactly what was different and I was disappointed to find out that it still had an 18 hour battery life. However, through my experience it can last closer to 30 hours per charge. But I do only use it as a watch and occasionally a timer so I imagine that having an influence on battery life.,It also was fully connected and updated within an hour and came with about 80 percent battery life.,The only downside is that it doesn’t come with a charging brick however this is standard for Apple as they stopped including bricks years ago. You still get the cable though.,All in all I love it and I love the deep red color that this watch is!

Save yourself time and money and purchase an earlier generation.  It's hard to justify this purchase price for marginal improvements from earlier iterations.  The Corporate Greed stinks, with their ruse of changing the prior iteration of charger to a USB system, so you need to purchase new stuff all around.  Yes, they include the cable with the USB-C, but the CHEAPOS don't include the plug.  Further, the one I received a couple weeks ago has been having non-stop charging issues and the battery life has been POOR.  Count on spending another $100 if you want the authentic plug and a second set.  Then again, maybe they're brilliant and they did all this nonsense to raise my heart rate to hit my fitness goals.

I have been wanting an apple watch, and finally purchased one.  I was a little leary with the battery life only being 18 hours, but it actually lasts for more than 24 hours!  I fully charge my watch each day (because I wear it to bed), and it only gets down to about 40% by the time I charge it again.  The calling and texting from the watch is awesome!  If you have been on the fence about getting one, then get off it, and buy one!

This is my first Apple Watch. I bought it from Apple and I love it. Still learning all it has to offer. I am disappointed, however, in the display. This series is touted to be more rugged than previous series. I am not that rough and, after less than 2 months, I already have 2 large scratches (see picture). At first I had a plastic film on it, but once I got active, moisture accumulated underneath. There are/were no covers available, plus I didn’t want to add bulk to the already large display. Of course the warranty doesn’t cover this. Eventually I will use my AppleCare+ to replace it. :(

So I’m only writing to say I have no idea what’s with some of these reviews. Okay no IT doesn’t come with a 9.99 block to usb-c. Big deal. If you can spend $400 bucks on a watch I think we can get that piece. It DOES come with the magnetic charger super fast charge chord that is $30 bucks. Also this watch syncs perfectly fine. I’ve bought 3 so far. For people that claim to be tech savvy but took 6 hours? I’m pretty with it still but other than saying did I want to sync it to my phone AFTER updating the phone it was fine. You buy a tech wifi product and it’s going to need updates but other than it telling and showing you how to sync up your phone there’s literally nothing to this. I bought it for my 82 year old mother . Showed her in minutes how to take an ECG, and pulse ox. Send a message, make a call, talk to Siri, set an appointment , reminder, alarm, Use the calendar , Set and measure her activity and set her ICE so if she falls and doesn’t get up the phone will contact us. For what it is and all it’s features , ease of use, this thing is amazing. I bought it on the $349. Price which really is pretty remarkable for all of it’s features. Lot’s of complaining here for something that’s a pretty amazing and bonus with an emergency alert for her to get help. I’m not sure how much people feel is okay to pay for all of this but for me it’s one of my favorite things and seeing my moms face light up and marvel over this thing makes me say it’s money well spent. Apple is a business, so is Verizon, Cable companies , service providers any many other monthly expenses that overcharge and don’t include all the accessories you need either. Apps are also money makers but some of them make our lives convenient. Go on you tube and look up how to set up your phones/watches. It shouldn’t take anyone 6 hours. From the time my mom opened it, while on a FaceTime call with my brother in Germany within literally 5 minutes it was syncing to her phone. Nothing difficult about it.

The iOS is horrible, frustrating, and counter intuitive. Want a stopwatch? Not on this device! Oh it has a stopwatch that is useless garbage. After one minute, the only thing it displays is 1:—:—. What genius thought of this? It’s not saving battery, the display is still on! You can raise your wrist and the numbers appear, but if I have a heavy dumbbell in my hand or I’m stabilizing it in my lap, I can’t move my wrist. Just have the flipping numbers on screen!! FFS. Do you want to know what minute you’re on after 70 seconds? Tough sh**, the screen switches to the time. So now you’re forced to bring up your wrist. And yes, I’ve looked up and changed every setting possible. Nothing I do prevents this. Well, why don’t you download a third part app? Hey, let’s try that. That was a massive headache itself and after I finally did download a third party stopwatch app that showed all of the numbers, the amazing, intuitive Apple iOS darkens and reverts to the time. Un-flipping-believable. Want to turn that setting off? Tough sh**, Mr. Customer, you can only look at the app for 70 seconds, so screw your three minute timer, peasant. “What you need to do is toggle the hide sensitive complications options on or off.” Guess what, that doesn’t work. Not after 70 seconds. While I’m talking about the display, sometimes an app view screen shows up randomly and I literally can’t do anything to get out of it. The only option I have is to turn it off and back on again. That’s extremely frustrating. Also, they need to figure out which direction the scroll when is used for. One screen the scroll wheel moves the screen in the direction you push the wheel (up is up and down is down), but when you go to move the cursor to edit text, down on the wheel moves the cursor up. Why? Why would they do this? Well we’re on the subject of text, the talk to text on this watch is atrocious. I can say the exact same thing on my iPhone and it works great. The watch simply does a turd job at understanding talk to text. When I do scroll down to go up and select a word to change it to something that I actually said instead of what it wrote, the options simply aren’t there. Ever. Also, when I’m on the workout app tracking my heart rate and I switch to a Stopwatch app to track my time in between sets, I looked down at my watch to check the time and it switched back to the workout app! That’s so extremely frustrating. When I switch to another app I want to look at that flipping app. I don’t want you to change to the time, I don’t want you to change apps regardless of what you think I want to see. It’s little stuff like this that makes me want to ask, will it blend? Sometimes I think putting it down the garbage disposal or in a Vitamix would make me much happier due to the frustration I have with the iOS. What stops me from doing that? The hardware. The hardware is really amazing. I love the way it feels in my wrist, I love the heart rate monitor which never drops my heart rate (unlike every Fitbit or Mio watch I’ve had). The screen is fantastic, the haptics are really nice and not overbearing. For the amount that this thing cost the fact that the software is so crippling there’s no way I can recommend someone purchase this until they get the iOS fixed.

Produto incrível! Não há o que dizer. Como designer gráfico trabalho com diversos programas Adobe e o equipamento me atende perfeitamente mesmo tendo eu diversificadas tarefas simultâneas em usos contínuo. Comprei pela portabilidade, duração de bateria e velocidade. Gastei também quase R$500 em acessórios para funcionar com meu setup anterior, mas estava ciente.,Comprei por um preço justo e estou satisfeito.

O computador chegou antes da entrega prevista; o vendedor respondeu a todas as minhas perguntas com rapidez; o produto é original, embalado.,Ótima experiência. !,o computador é excelente. Chip M1 , super rápido. A câmera para video chamadas tem ótima resolução.,Leve, pequeno. perfeito

Quanto ao computador não usei o suficiente pra encontrar algum ponto de atenção, atendeu minhas expectativas e necessidades. Vale o investimento, não faz dois anos comprei um laptop com excelente configuração e que mesmo assim não funciona. A apple não tem isso, tudo deles cumpre e dura, por isso, no final o produto se paga. Pesquisei muito qual computador comprar e o vendedor e fiz a melhor escolha possível, pelo equipamento e loja! Recebi o note impecável, super bem embalado, e muito antes da data prevista. Antes de enviar fui contatada pelo Rafael, da ByTech Info, ele me mandou foto da pacote, me senti bem assistida e segura. Recebi a NF junto, só tenho elogios e recomendações.

Como desenvolvedor de sistemas, os principais pontos fortes são: performance (apesar de 8gb de ram, se comportou de forma flúida inclusive com simuladores mobile ativos), bateria (programando, com simuladores ligados, e brilho alto, consumiu aprox 40% após 5 horas de uso intenso... impressionante) e mobilidade (muito leve, fino e não esquenta muito, poucas vezes ligou a ventoinha). Ponto negativo: por enquanto ainda existem algumas incompatibilidades de tecnologias com a arquitetura arm64 do M1, mas em geral há workarounds para superá-los. De forma geral, uma excelente compra
Não aceitou mais a senha e parou
It is light and sleek with fast running speed, satisfied with its performance.

Eu já tinha um Macbook Pro 2018, o telcado "borboleta" dele era pessimo, nunca tinha tido problemas de performance mas esquentava demais.,O chip M1 veio para revolucionar, além de melhorar a duração da bateria o processador nao esquenta nada e o teclado esta muito melhor do que anterior que ao meu ver era injusto comparado com o preço.,Esse computador na faixa de 9k esta muito justo comparado com sua perfomance.,É estranho falar isso vindo da Apple, mas pela primeira vez vejo como um ótimo custo beneficio para quem trabalha com computador.

This brand getting more and more complicated in simple things. My messages not working on watch. Samsung never failed me and easy to set up all messages and notifications flawlessly working. This garbage going back to apple. For $460? lol. what a crap

Thought Apple neglected to include a charger with a new watch and called customer service to check.. Was told chargers are no longer included to reduce the impact to the environment. If you believe in Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and Apple worrying about the environment! I have some ocean front property for sale in Yuma, Arizona. So angry about being fleeced for another charger…

I don't understand why people - even real techies are complaining about the charging situation of the watch.  Can't you read?  Need to do your due diligence before buying.  It says what's in the box.  You can buy an Apple 20W charging block for $20.00.  I guarantee you'll need it for the future.  You can also buy adapters.  If you just read what's in the box, you could have avoided lots of stress.  Everything would have arrived together.  As to the updates, from what I understand the updates need go in sequence.  If you don't have the latest, you need to update.  If you don't have one or 2 previous updates you need to add those updates first.  I am an old dog who hates to learn new tricks, Apple make things easier and I'm happier for it.  Thanks Apple

This watch comes with no means of connecting it to electricity to charge it.  It has as C connection and they want another $19 for a plug that allows you to connect to the electricity to get a charge.  I went elsewhere and bought the charger, I refused to give them extra money.  It was not the $19 it was the fact that they would sell a product that could not be used out of the box.

I speak for many in the track and field world who have tried and tried to enjoy Apple Watch as a fitness device. Problem is the lack of a physical start/stop button makes timing short races impossible. Whether you are timing yourself on repeat 400s or timing other athletes on 100s, 200s, 800s or miles. Fact is we sweat a lot on the track especially during summer workouts. We need a start and stop button!! Apple clearly hasn’t asked a track athlete’s opinion on this. The Watch is a great device for daily life. However it shouldn’t advertise as a fitness device. If stoping the clock during a summer workout is not possible this it is not a fitness device.

I’m sure the product is fine, I can’t check because it’s a Xmas gift and I don’t want to mess up the setup process for my wife. However, the watch came already opened. This obviously did not come from the factory, nor did they even attempt to present it that way and it’s very apparent that somebody has gone through the box it comes in for who knows what reason. Just takes away from the presenting aspect. My wife now has to open a $400 Apple Watch on Xmas that looks like it came in a used box. Very disappointing.

I had the series 3 for three years, and never scratched the screen — I use the watch daily and have a very active lifestyle. The series 7, within two weeks, I noticed a huge scratch on it and did not have any incidents where I would have scratched it like this. I googled this problem and discovered many people are experiencing the same thing. Apparently while it's more shatter resistant, it's less scratch resistant. Wish I knew. Definitely get a screen protector, I'm extremely disappointed to have such a gouge in a VERY expensive watch.

My Apple Watch series 7 was a great investment because I use it multiple times every day: day of the month for writing checks, set timer for cooking, outside temperature, outside weather, battery charge, DJIA, tracking sleep. The quarter hour chimes keep my on track throughout the day and serve as a good antidote to procrastination.  The Infographics watch face allows instant monitoring of up to 7 functions ("complications") simultaneously.  For me, one device on my wrist is more convenient than multiple devices in various locations:  in my pocket, on my wall, and on my desk.

Amazing - I received this watch as a gift.  Turns out the charging cable is faulty.  Chatted with them online, they told me to go to an apple store who confirmed the cable was faulty after a long examination.  They didn't have any of the new usb-c charging cables and at first said they couldn't send one to me, that I had to come back to the store.  After pressing them, I was told that apple care would call me that night which they did.  They would send one to me as long as I sent the faulty cable back.  9 days later, it hasn't shipped and support continues to fumble around for a response.  They could send me an older model cable...they could send me a new dual mag cable...but no, they continue without a clue.  So much for a premium product and excellent support.  I'm sure the cable costs them <$1.  What's my time and frustration worth?  What's a bad review worth??

The watch face had a very visible scratch right out of the box. When I contacted Amazon support they directed me to Apple support and said I would have to send the  BRAND NEW watch in to be replaced. I think that is kind of ridiculous that I spent this kind of money on a watch that was damaged before I got it, and now I have to send it to someone else for repair. The Apple support sight is no help what so ever unless you have a software problem. I can't even just send the watch back to Amazon for a refund without going through Amazon support. At this point I just want to send it back for a refund, but Amazon and Apple are making that difficult!
The screen resolution is crystal clear, camera takes great pictures and you can't beat the price!!!

Já uso produtos da Apple há vários anos e nenhuma marca a supera. Esse MacBook Pro é sensacional e, como todos os demais produtos da marca, funciona perfeitamente, além de ter bateria com longa duração, o que me surpreendeu. Portanto, se você pensa em comprar um notebook de nível profissional e com qualidade garantida, essa é a máquina certa.

Simplesmente perfeito, chegou muito rápido, veio embalado em várias caixas e plástico bolha, com todo cuidado do mundo, tudo certo com a nota fiscal, validei e consta tudo certinho, recomendo demais esse vendedor, podem comprar sem dúvidas.

Utilizo para desenvolver aplicativos, o ecossistema Apple é muito bom. Único ponto negativo é que existe apenas duas saídas USB-C, necessitando de inúmeros adaptadores, ou docs, que geralmente esquentam bastante.

Adorei, pra quem gosta de Mac vale muito a pena. Lindo, pequeno e leve , teclas firmes, o touch bar é fantástico, o trackpad é gigante (comparado com o 2012), silencioso (nem parece que está ligado), veio tudo novinho com o Big Sur.

I was hesitant to buy one of these Apple watches, I thought they looked a bit clunky and I was not sure I was going to use all (any of) the features. But I’ve been wearing it now for a couple weeks and I absolutely love it. The phone even rings on this watch and I can answer it and speak into my wrist watch, just the way they used to do in the old sci-fi TV shows… :-)),The ECG is great to use, as is the exercise and activity app.  Also I get news flashes.  Just love my watch!

I received this watch yesterday. I may rewrite or add to this review later. Day one didn’t go well. The first problem encountered was software update. That took over 30 minutes and then I had to put the watch on the charger to finish updating. An hour later, I began setting up the watch. Each click screen (Accept - do later), the watch froze up. Two hours after starting, the watch finally works, almost. The cellular phone feature didn’t work until 24 hours later. I placed the watch on charge again at 8:00 pm that night. I put the watch back on at 10:30 pm to go to bed with 100% charge. I use the watch as an alarm clock. I was awakened at 7:30 am. The watch showed 79 % charged. So far I have had to charge the watch twice a day. The watch comes with two small bands and no charger.

This was a great Christmas present. My significant other really enjoys to wear the watch, the original band that comes with it is also small enough for people with very slim spindly antenna like wrists to wear comfortably. It has many nice features including weirdly enough a strange ability to read how much oxygen is in your blood that has something to do with lights and colors and sounds and the feeling of being on a giant rock that is moving through space at incredible speeds, you are alive. Look up, look up, I see you now. You look nice, take care of yourself. Enjoy this product by Apple, goodbye!
It’s certainly bold, the red. I am going from green, pink and now red. I so happy I did..,This is just beautifully made, feature rich and quality.

The 2020 iPad 10.2, which I own, was widely reviewed as the best iPad for most people. It blows away tablets from all other manufacturers, and will do most of what the more expensive iPads will do, albeit not as quickly and not as attractively. It's a great, excellent bang-for-the buck tablet for media consumption and light creative work (email, short documents). If you add a bluetooth keyboard, which I do, you can quickly bang out long emails and longer documents. It's a very versatile and portable device with an all-day battery.,That said, I'm upgrading to the 2021 model, which is a substantial upgrade over 2020 version at same price. Contrary to the statement by another reviewer, the improvement to the front-facing camera is a big deal. The resolution is markedly better, which is good for FaceTime calls, the Center Stage feature, which isn't available even on the iPad Air, is an upgrade for video, and the TrueTone display is more satisfying to many (I like it).,Moreover, the base memory for the 2021 model is, at 64 gb, twice that of the 2020 model which was pretty tight although usable at 32 gb. I bumped up against that limit a couple of times, so I love getting double the memory.,The 2021 model has a moderately faster CPU chip and substantially faster GPU (graphic) function, neither of which matter at this point for my use.,I probably would have hung onto the 2020 model which is adequate to most of my tasks, despite the relatively low memory. But Apple and a blue Big Box store offer pretty good trade-ins on the 2020. By taking advantage of price matching and trade-in of the 2020, I'm able to get the 202110.2 for $80. It's well worth $80 to me for the additional storage and the greatly improved front facing camera. You might be able to sell a 2020 for more than I got on the trade-in, but I didn't explore that.,In brief, the 2021 10.2 inch iPad should be on your short list for tablets--check out the reviews. And even if you have a recent model low end iPad like me, it could be worth your while to upgrade.

Never did earbuds before, and I decided to try these instead of headphones. They allow me great versatility which I hadn't thought about beforehand. The sound is fantastic, and they work well with my Android. Definitely a good buy.

So i have had every cheap pair of buds on the Earth.  I break them or one side dies out and they all sound like crap.  These are top notch and sound so good.  My daughter bought them for me for Christmas and i am very very happy with them.

I purchased these for my son, who had a pair before, but lost them.  He synced them with his phone, and as he started listening to music, the AirPods kept disconnecting.  I'm not sure these were new at all; maybe refurbished, but certainly not new.

Pros: Integrate well with Apple product. Setup was quick and easy. Noise cancellation is on par with competition.,Cons: Audio isolation was good but overall audio quality is pretty flat. I use other premium bluetooth headphones in the past. This one is nothing compared to them in terms of audio quality

I have spent years buying and getting rid of different types of air buds. These are perfect. They’re comfortable, they have great sound, and they’re extremely lightweight. I also love that they recharge in their own case. I would buy these again if I ever needed to. I highly recommend them.

I am a big fan of Bluetooth ear buds and have purchased several different brands in search of the best. I finally got these after they made them compatible with my Android phone. And wow! There is a definite difference in the sound and noise cancellation. I am very happy with this purchase.

Connection with iPhone is flawless. Connection with windows laptop is easy. Not much to complain about. The noise cancelation is alright for ear buds. The only earbuds that ever fit in my ear without falling out while running. (Because of the silicone tips)

Feels solid in the ears. Noise cancelling feature is easy to engage. Sound quality is excellent. iPhone is clear both voice and reception. I only wish I could control the volume on the buttons vs. Siri or directly from the iPhone.

Okay, I've been an Android fan since, well, since the very beginning...I still am if I'm being honest. I have also spent a ridiculously large amount of $$ on smart watches over the years starting with the original Moto 360 (anyone remember that flat tire?). It LOOKED cool, especially that round face, but performance-wise, well, it was kinda terrible. The battery life was insultingly horrible (it would lose 7% in the ten minute drive to work while just sitting on my wrist doing nothing). But the potential was there. In finally switched to Samsung's Tizen at the introduction of the Gear S2. What a great watch that was. I went on to the Gear S3, the Gear Sport, the Galaxy Watch, the GW3 and then I heard the news: Samsung was going back to Wear OS. This disappointed me greatly. Over the years I have owned well over a dozen watches utilizing Wear OS (or Android Wear before that) and while I loved a lot about many of them, they ALL suffered from the stuttering and glitching that plagues essentially ALL Wear OS devices. Some have managed to work around that to produce the best version they possibly can (TicWatch Pro 3 and the Oppo Watch are just 2 examples) but each had at least something that just didn't work properly - and I don't blame either manufacturer for this. It's an ongoing problem with Wear OS itself. Slowly, I began to warm to the idea that maybe, just MAYBE Samsung will make it work the way it was always supposed to work. So, I bought the Galaxy Watch 4.,Did Samsung fix Wear OS? In a word: NO. It still suffers from glitches, hiccups and stuttering and apps not opening properly and/or timely. At times it works just great (which is more often than not, but still...), I have a fairly expensive watch that ruins what otherwise ought to be a smoother experience than what I'm getting. My Galaxy Watch 3 runs fantastic (it runs on TIzen software and not Wear OS) and honestly, I have had zero issues with it since I got it over a year ago, nor any with my previous Tizen watches including the Gear S2, S3, Gear Sport and original Galaxy Watch. I have had intermittent issues with the GW4 since the day I brought it home. To be fair, I have heard many people who claim that their Watch 4's have run flawlessly since they bought theirs...but I cannot speak to their experience, only the one I've had - but I brought it up to be fair.,I have done a LOT of research regarding all different kinds of smart watches, and you know what you almost never hear from the majority of apple watch owners? You don't hear about not getting a notification, or stuttering and glitches here and there. Sure, I'm sure they exist, but the overwhelming majority generally say the same thing: the watch JUST WORKS. Honestly, that is all I really care about. Does it do what it claims and does it do it consistently? From an Android Fanboy, I can say this without reservation: the apple watch works and does so CONSISTENTLY. I simply cannot say that about my GW4 or any other Wear OS device I have used over the last 6-8 years.,Okay, now why did I switch? Well, when I heard that the apple watch could be used without an iPhone, it really caught my attention. Seriously, an apple watch that can be set up so the user does not need an iPhone?? Well that's just what I wanted to hear. The truth is, once the watch is set up with "Family Setup" as long as it's an LTE model watch, you do not need to have it paired with an iPhone AT ALL...however (and this is a biggie) - you STILL need an iPhone to set it up initially. That sucked. But - I have enough friends with iPhone's that I took the plunge anyway.,The watch looks phenomenal BTW. I got the blue model and that new watch face that takes advantage of the larger screen is fantastic. Since this is my very first apple watch, I can't speak to how well it compares to earlier models, so I'm sorry about that. Honestly however, having not used a previous model before, I just don't see that there is a difference that is noticeable when compared to my friends who have earlier model apple watches. The major thing I like is exactly what I wanted most: a watch that is reliable. It took a bit of getting used to because I have been so familiar with Wear OS and Tizen watches for so long, but it isn't difficult, just takes a little time, that's all. I haven't always liked the apple rectangular shape...but slowly, it grew on me. It was always made really well, of that there has never been any doubt, but the series 7 is just great to look at.,The one thing keeping my review from 5 to only 4 stars was the pretty HUGE omission of the charging block. As you've no doubt gathered by now, I'm a android guy and always have been. My last 4 phones have all used USB-C chargers...but none of them came with blocks that the USB-C cord went into, they all had the USB-C port on only ONE end, not both. It's fair to assume the majority of apple users do not own one of these, either. Meaning, it's an unnecessary EXTRA expense you absolutely MUST make in order to even be able to use your watch - unless you have a charger from a previous apple watch which you can still use, but you won't be able to take advantage of the faster charging time. For what apple is charging for this watch, leaving this out is nothing shy of a ginormous cash grab on their part, and it's rather blatant and disappointing. Seriously guys, this is simple greed...and if anyone at their HQ bothers to read any of these reviews will note that there are quite a few upset genuine apple fanatics who really are quite upset by this same situation, so I am definitely NOT alone here. Wise up apple or you'll force longtime fans into the arms of Wear OS simply to make a statement.,With that said, the watch operates extraordinarily well. I have seen zero hiccups that I see each time I turned on my Galaxy Watch 4 (seriously, EVERY time I turn it on, I get a notification that tells me I have voice mail, but when I check, there is nothing there - literally EVERY SINGLE TIME I turn the watch on. After 3 months...it got old...and now it simply makes me mad). I've always heard of the great haptics on apple devices and now I know what they mean. Samsung does a pretty good job as well on their watches, don't get me wrong, but these are just, well, better. It's hard to describe unless you've actually worn one to feel the difference. My TicWatch Pro 3 is actually a pretty good Wear OS watch, it really is...however, the haptics are so friggin' anemic I miss 90% of my notification vibrations due to the poor haptic engine it has. (this is an issue with hundreds of thousands of other TicWatch Pro 3 owners...it's on many online threads if you're curious) That isn't the case here with the series 7. I get ALL my notifications and in a timely manner and that on-screen keyboard with swipe-like ability is fantastic. It's not as good as the Google keyboard, but it isn't far behind...and for quick text input, especially if you're in a loud environment where you cannot use voice dictation, or you're in a quiet place or you simply don't want people around you to hear what you're replying, this is a wonderful tool and it works pretty great. Kudos to apple for adding it. I want to mention the haptic engine again...it's actually quite impressive. It vibrates in a totally different manner than ALL other smart watches I've ever owned. It works beautifully and it is hard to miss a notification due to it's efficiency. I swear, if my TicWatch had a decent haptic engine and better music-transfer capability, I may never have even considered getting the apple watch at all.,This the only smartwatch besides Samsung to make transferring music to your watch pretty seamless. OR SO I THOUGHT. I tried almost a dozen different programs supposedly designed to help convert my mp3's to easily transfer to my phone and then onto my watch. Almost every one would cap you at transferring 10 songs per day ONLY - unless you paid money. Even iTunes was a problem saying that I had to change this setting on my phone in order to transfer music...yet no matter how often I changed the setting, it still said I needed to do the same thing again. I deleted iTunes and re-downloaded it and tried again. Nope. Same issue. I finally discovered a program called, "SynciOS" which allowed me to transfer music in a pretty intuitive manner and do it ridiculously quick. Not sure why it took so long to be able to do something so simple, but sheesh, this was essentially the only thing that really frustrated me regarding my series 7 watch. Samsung makes this process STUPID EASY to do and sorry apple fans, is FAR SUPERIOR to how apple does it. All other Wear OS watches are no better at making this an easy process and in fact, can make it even more difficult.,I love how on my hikes, while listening to music on my watch, I'll get updates every mile I've reached. This is another great feature...but its one that is done better with the Galaxy Watches. The Original GW and the GW3 and GW4 all give you this same information but goes a few steps further. Samsung tells you when you've reached that mile, but also tells you how many steps you've taken to get there AND your heart rate. It only takes 3-4 extra seconds and it works great. The difference between Tizen and Wear OS however is that with TIzen the music would halt while the watch reads out that info thru the bluetooth earbuds, while Wear OS it just slightly lowers the volume of music and tells you the information. Apple lowers the music volume much lower which makes hearing your metrics much easier, but still, the more information the better as far as I'm concerned. Yesterday I wore both my GW3 and the apple watch and they each marked every mile within probably 4-5 seconds of one another - or roughly 15-20 feet difference, which says they both were pretty spot-on for how they measured distance. They both were within about 7 steps of each other as well and heart rate were off by 1 or 2 beats per minute. That tells me either they are both accurate, or both are off by roughly the same amount. There may be a few workout routines that apple doesn't cover which Samsung does and vice versa, but they do all the one's I personally use regularly and that's what counts as far as I'm concerned. Great implementation, too.,All in all, you've made this Android user a convert. Though, I still prefer using my Samsung phone. Sorry guys.,***UPDATE***,Battery life compared to my GW4 is simply astonishing - especially considering how much people whine about it online. Case in point: yesterday I braved the snow and 15 degree temps and walked the 5 miles home from work for my exercise. I wore both my Galaxy Watch 4 and apple watch 7. Keep in mind before I left, I topped off my GW4 til it was at 100%, something I could not do with my apple watch since I do not have a spare charger at work like I do with my Samsung watches, which seem to need it more often. I will stipulate that after a few weeks using my GW4 the battery life improved significantly as it "learned" my habits and adjusted accordingly. I used GPS on both to keep track of my walk, and listened to music downloaded to both watches and switched from one to the other exactly at the half-way point to make it fair. By the time I reached home, my GW4 was down to 61%. Now keep in mind I had been using my apple watch since 5am that morning and wasn't able to charge it before leaving for home. When I hit home my apple watch 7 was still at 79%. That is astonishing to me...and an enormously HUGE difference. I have suspected the battery life was better, but not by THAT much. I just looked it up, and the 45mm apple Watch 7 has a battery size of 309 mAh, while the GW4 has a battery size of 361 mAh. Sorry, but this is a GINORMOUS apple win here. It seems every other review I read about the newest apple watch, one of the chief complaints is battery life, but when compared to the GW4, I cannot help but be happy with it's performance so far. After having used the apple watch for over a week, using the GW4 reminded me (again) that Wear OS just isn't quite there yet. The crazy glitches that plague this system, the incessant notification of voicemail that is NEVER there 100% of the time whenever I turn the watch off and turn it back on again, the notification that my watch is playing media that isn't there, or that it's paired with a kindle that I have never paired it with, the slowness of opening apps and closing them again, the problem of pulling down the settings menu and how it works about half the time I try to pull it down, or scroll up working only part of the time, or how I close all apps only to discover some still open - apps I've never tried to open since the day I bought my watch...the list goes on and on. You know what glitches I've had with the apple watch? NONE. Seriously. I haven't had one single hiccup since I turned this device on. I truly wished this were not the case with my Samsung. The honest truth is I wouldn't even have an apple watch were it not for my sour experience with the newest Galaxy Watch. I still hope that a future update will correct most of these problems, and if so, I will be thrilled to see them implemented and will gladly state so. Problem is, I don't think this is Samsung's problem, it's an issue with Wear OS and Samsung can only do so much to correct it. I DO find it interesting that my older TicWatch Pro 3 has shown far fewer issues and glitches than the GW4 in pretty much every situation...so maybe its a combination of Wear OS and Samsung's version of Wear OS 3.0. Either way, I've been very disappointed in my experience and wish that they had never switched from Tizen in the first place. Oh well. Time will tell if Wear OS can correct these issues or not.,The body composition feature is cool on the GW4. I really thought it would be more useful, though. I suppose it can be, but - for me at least - it simply hasn't been something that I've been able to get any kind of genuine use out of. Reportedly it can actually measure your blood pressure...but on a watch? I honestly cannot see how accurate that could be using any kind of method the way the watch is set up. Every reputable medical site I have looked at says the tech is far too new and simply isn't capable - yet anyway - of accurately being able to measure blood pressure monitoring. Kudos to Samsung for initiating it, but at this point, I wouldn't put a whole lot of stock on accuracy.,Charging...so, since this is my first apple watch, I can't compare it's supposedly 33% faster charging over previous models...but I WILL say it's faster than the Galaxy Watch 4, 3, Original Galaxy Watch etc. and my TicWatch Pro 3...however, I have an Oppo Watch (which was clearly a ripoff of the apple watch design, but in their defense, they did a STELLAR job with it), now that watch charges FAST. Exactly how much faster, I cannot say for certain, but let's just say all of those other models I mentioned pale in comparison. I just find it absurd that apple did not include a charging block. An utterly imbecilic decision.

I expected the latest watch to work seamlessly with the latest iPhone.  This is the latest watch.  I have the latest iPhone.,I'm in recovery from two episodes of a dangerous heart arrhythmia and my exercise program consists of approximately 1 hour moderately intense walks each day.  At minimum, I wanted the watch to count steps, maybe measure distance as well, and measure and keep track of my heart rate.  I also expected to be able to access this information fairly easily and when I wanted to on my iPhone as well as on the watch.,Apple buried the pedometer if it has one, and if it has one, you can't put it on the watch face I just spent a long time selecting as the one that I liked.  Apparently Apple restricts third parties from creating useful watch faces, so there aren't that many, and there isn't one I could put what I wanted on.,I installed a pedometer app.  I bought the watch having been assured by the salesman that this watch had or this watch even was a pedometer.  What am I doing installing a pedometer app?  This seemed like buying an iPhone and having to install a phone app.  If you know the watch OS, I hope it wouldn't take you that long to set this up just the way you want it, but I didn't have the patience.  I think I got the number of steps to display but then there wasn't a place to put the heart rate.  I expected less hassle for this simple function.,I opened the iPhone Watch app.  I'm sure there is a way to get it out of the Settings screen, but at this point, as I was about to refresh my perception of how this app wasn't that easy to use, I can't get it to do anything except alter various settings.  I can't back out of the Settings into the program itself.  I've only been using computers since 1982 or so, when I studied assembly language on a machine with 1K Ram and cassette tape instead of a hard drive, so it could be that I'm not capable of figuring out how to operate the easy to use Apple software interface.,I even have an Apple Watch for Dummies book, the latest edition.  I ended up looking online for solutions to problems as they came up because for me the book was full of a lot of tips and info except no info on the particular problem, whatever it was, that I had.,Apple doesn't even consider the type of exercise that I am doing at the moment, i.e. fairly gentle walking coming back from a serious heart issue, as exercise.  So they program their software out of the box to ignore the type of walking I do, so people say.  Maybe the watch can be tweaked or if I muttered the right incantation it might decide my walks are exercise,  but as I looked for info on how to make the watch display information about my proposed walks, the first warnings I ran into were that walks are not exercise in the Apple ecosystem unless they are of a certain intensity.  I don't know because I couldn't set up the watch well enough to even take it for a walk before I gave up and told my wife, who gave it to me as a present, that I was going to send it back.,The screen is beautiful.  The 45mm watch seems too big and bulky for me and I am 6 foot 1 inch with big hands.  The aesthetically appealing watch faces are the least customizable.  I made sure to turn the alarm off but it went off at 6:30 am anyway, and it would not manually stop sounding off every few minutes after that.  Etc.  I'm sure I could have found some setting other than alarm OFF that would have made the alarm not be set to go off tomorrow morning, but...

As already posted in previous reviews, this watch doesn’t come with the usb c brick that you need to charge it, so buy yourself one when you order your new watch. I already had one because I recently bought an iPhone 13 pro. That and the shorter battery life of this watch are the only drawbacks. You’re going to have to charge this watch every 24 hours. That being said, it’s a wonderful watch. It came in sealed, Apple packaging. The watch box was sealed on both ends. I mention this because of a few other reviews that complain of unsealed packaging and missing items. It has many features and I love that the health app integrates with the watch and you can view all of the data collected by the watch there. I ordered and received the 41mm. I’m a woman and I find that an adequate size for my wrist and I’m actually glad that I didn’t get the 45mm because it would have been too big and I’m not a dainty female with a small wrist. It has a lot of apps available and I took about a third of them off and that made the ones I wanted easier to view. It has a lot of watch faces to choose from and there are watch face apps available as well. I would have preferred a different color but with all of the watch bands available to choose from and different colors of hard screen protectors out there, it really didn’t matter and it’s a great price. I did purchase the offered insurance for $79 as well. All in all, it’s a great watch. The last comment I’d make is that something as basic as a wall charger that’s required to charge the product that you’ve just spent several hundred $$ on, should include it. Are you listening Apple? Probably not, oh well.
